question.content: Sincere students / like you and he should study / regularly to pass the examination. SSC CHSL Tier II (02 / 11 / 2023)

options.text: like you and he should study

solution.content: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: While astrology has/ a long history / it is generally/ considered pseudoscience. SSC CHSL Tier II (10 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: considered pseudoscience The ‘pseudoscience’ mentioned in the given sentence is not specific and we generally use the indefinite article ‘a’ before a non-specific noun. Hence, ‘considered a pseudoscience’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I have three sisters: / Meera is the elder / and Charu is the youngest. SSC CHSL Tier II (10 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: Meera is the elder ‘Elder’ must be replaced with ‘eldest’. The definite article ‘the’ is used before a superlative degree. Hence, ‘Meera is the eldest’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A man who has been accused of fraud / in an earlier job, he will never be / welcome in any other organisation. SSC CHSL Tier II (10 / 01 / 2024)

options.text: A man who has been accused of fraud
in an earlier job, he will never be

answer: in an earlier job, he will never be

solution.content: in an earlier job, he will never be ‘A man’ is already mentioned as a subject of this sentence. We cannot use ‘he’ in the sentence as it becomes the case of superfluousness(not necessary). Therefore, ‘he’ must be removed from the sentence. Hence, ‘in an earlier job, will never be’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: It is a well-known fact/ that the Monarchy is / not the best form /of governance. SSC CHSL Tier II (10 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: that the Monarchy is Article ‘the’ must be removed. No article is used before the forms of government such as democracy, plutocracy, dictatorship, monarchy. Hence, ‘that Monarchy is’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Specialists say that this method speeds up language learning tremendously. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: No error . The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Two elderly gentlemen told the rather improbable story to mislead the police personnel. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: told the rather improbable ‘The’ must be replaced with ‘a’. Article ‘the’ is used for specific or particular nouns but the ‘story’ mentioned in the sentence is not specific. Hence, ‘told a rather improbable’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We cannot postpone discussion on this issue although it is urgent. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: although it is urgent. ‘Although’ must be replaced with ‘as / because’. The issue is urgent, that is why discussion on it can not be postponed. Here, we need a connector to show the cause or reason. Hence, ‘because it is urgent’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Are you yet afraid of going out in the dark? SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: Are you yet ‘Yet’ must be replaced with ‘still’. ‘Yet’ is used to show contrast between two events. ‘Still’ is used to show that an action was happening in the past and continuing in the present. Hence, ‘Are you still’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Rohit Sharma’s century was very acclaimed in the media. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: very acclaimed ‘Very’ must be replaced with ‘much’. ‘Very’ is used with present participles(V ing ), not with past participles(V 3 ). Hence, ‘much acclaimed’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: You can take a horse to the water but you cannot make it to drink. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: make it to drink. ‘To’ must be removed. There are some verbs that take a bare infinitive(without ‘to’) after them. These are ‘make, let, bid, see, watch, observe’. Hence, ‘make it drink’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the most appropriate option that rectifies the error(s) in the following sentence. One must do his / her duty proparly. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

options.text: One must do ones duty properly.
One must do one’s duty properly.
One must do once duty proparly.
One must do one’s duti proprly.

answer: One must do one’s duty properly.

solution.content: One must do one’s duty properly. Each pronoun has its own possessive adjective. For example - (I/my), (he/his), (she/her), (one/one’s). Hence, option (b) is the correct sentence.

question.content: It is time someone takes concrete steps to alleviate the problem of unemployment in the country. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: It is time someone takes Simple Past Tense(Subject + V 2 ) is used after phrases such as “It is time / It is about time / It is high time”. Therefore, ‘takes’ will be replaced with ‘took(V 2 )’. Hence, ‘It is time someone took’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The food was not as delicious as we had expected. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: None than you deserve credit for the success of this project. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: None than you ‘Than’ must be replaced with ‘but’. The correct phrase is ‘none but’ or ‘none other than’, which means ‘only’. Hence, ‘none but you’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Hold my hand lest you should not get lost in the huge crowd at the fair. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: lest you should not ‘Lest’ is used without ‘not’. Hence, ‘lest you should’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I will definitely accept the responsibility while the time comes. SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: while the time comes ‘While’ must be replaced with ‘when’. The phrase ‘when the time comes’ is used to state an action that will be done in the suitable circumstances. Hence, ‘when the time comes’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Let us work out the details of our endeavour, shouldn’t we? SSC CPO Tier II (08 / 01 / 2024)

solution.content: shouldn’t we ‘Shall we’ is the correct question tag for an imperative sentence starting with ‘let us’. Hence, ‘shall we’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This is the book whom I wanted to buy. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

solution.content:
whom I ‘Whom’ must be replaced with ‘which’. ‘Whom’ is used for a person whereas ‘which’ is used for things(book).
Hence, ‘which I’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Everyone should respect those parents, teachers, and elders. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

solution.content: respect those ‘His’ is used with ‘everybody / everyone / somebody / someone / nobody / no one’ if the gender is unknown. Similarly, the given sentence talks about every single person, both male and female. Hence, ‘respect his’ is the most appropriate answer.
married happily ‘Happily’ is an adverb that will be used before the adjective ‘married’ to modify its meaning. Hence, ‘happily married’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The speaker’s emphasiss is on the present-day problems that are being faced by ordinary men of India. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

solution.content: The speaker’s emphasiss is ‘Emphasis’ is the correct spelling.

question.content: They want to live in first floor of this building. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

solution.content: live in first floor ‘Live in first floor’ must be replaced with ‘live on the first floor’. Definite article ‘the’ is used before a superlative degree adjective. ‘First’ is a superlative adjective. ‘On’ is used to indicate the surface on which something rests. ‘Floor’ is the bottom surface of a room. Hence, ‘live on the first floor’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We / has seen / that movie / before. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

solution.content: has seen According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘we’ is a plural subject that will take ‘have’ as a plural verb. Hence, ‘have seen’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The given sentence has an error. Choose the option that corrects the error Throw a rounder stone to create ripples in the water. SSC CGL Tier II (26 / 10 / 2023)

options.text: Throw the roundest stone to create ripples in the water.
Throw a more round stone to create ripples in the water.
Throw a more rounder stone to create ripples in the water.
Throw a round stone to create ripples in the water.

answer: Throw a round stone to create ripples in the water.

solution.content: Throw a round stone to create ripples in the water.(Correct) (a) Throw the roundest stone to create ripples in the water.(Incorrect Adjective) (b) Throw a more round stone to create ripples in the water.(Incorrect Adjective) (c) Throw a more rounder stone to create ripples in the water.(Incorrect Adjective)

question.content: The dancers swayed dainty on the stage last night. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: swayed dainty ‘Dainty’ must be replaced with ‘daintily’. The given sentence needs an adverb to modify the verb (swayed) and not an adjective(dainty). Hence, ‘swayed daintily’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We feed the horse oats for a week because it had eaten all the hay. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: it had eaten all the hay

solution.content: We feed the horse oats ‘Feed’ must be replaced with ‘fed’. The given sentence is in the past tense so it must have the verb in the past form(V 2 ) and not in the present form(feed). Hence, ‘We fed the horse oats(V 2 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: She will have participate / in the dance competition / by the time her father / returns from the tour. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: She will have participate ‘Participate’ must be replaced with ‘participated’. When we talk about something that will be completed before a specific time in the future, ‘Future perfect tense’(will/shall have + V 3 ) is used. Hence, ‘She will have participated’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: They will not attend / the event / as they’re going / away at end of April. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: away at end of April . We always place the definite article ‘the’ before ‘beginning’ and ‘end’. Hence, ‘away at the end of April’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I wanted to buy a candle holder, / but the store didn't have one. / So, I got a cake. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: I wanted to buy a candle holder
but the store didn't have one

solution.content: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: You arrived two days ago. By the time you leave, you will have spent nine days here. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: you will have spent nine days here

solution.content: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: The simple mistake which was committed by the boy haunted her for years
An simple mistake which was committed by the boy haunted her for years.
The simple mistake which was committed by an boy haunted her for years.
A simple mistake which was committed by an boy haunted her for years.

answer: The simple mistake which was committed by the boy haunted her for years

solution.content: The simple mistake which was committed by the boy haunted her for years.(Correct) (b) An simple mistake which was committed by the boy haunted her for years.(Incorrect Article) (c) The simple mistake which was committed by an boy haunted her for years.(Incorrect Article) (d) A simple mistake which was committed by an boy haunted her for years.(Incorrect Article)

question.content: There is a spectrum / of seas around that /land which attracts / tourists of all aging. SSC CPO 03 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: tourists of all aging ‘Aging’ must be replaced with ‘ages’. ‘Of all ages’ is a phrase which means people belonging to all age groups. Hence, ‘tourists of all ages’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Neem tastes / a little bitterly, / but is very useful. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: a little bitterly ‘Bitterly’ must be replaced with the adjective ‘bitter’. ‘Taste’ is a stative verb and stative verbs require an adjective after them, not an adverb. Hence, ‘a little bitter’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Rani was extreme upset with her results this year. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: extreme upset ‘Extreme’ must be replaced with ‘extremely’. The given sentence requires an adverb to modify the meaning of the adjective ‘upset’. Hence, ‘extremely upset’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The postman / delivers the letters / through hand, / door to door. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: through hand ‘By’ is used to show the means or method used to do something whereas ‘through’ is used to talk about the process by which something happens. Similarly, the given sentence shows that the postman delivers the letters using his hands. Hence, ‘by hand’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Luckily, I managed to get a room in the college hostel, and I move in there. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: Luckily, I managed to get a room

solution.content: and I move in there ‘Move’ must be replaced with ‘moved’. The given sentence is in Past Tense, so the verb must be used in the past form(moved). Hence, ‘and I moved there’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: There was no other book / in the English language / which is as interesting as this one SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: which is as interesting as this one

solution.content: There was no other book ‘Was’ must be replaced with ‘is’ as the given sentence is in present tense. Hence, ‘there is no other book’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I have never / come to / such a kind person / like my friend. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: come to ‘Come across’ is a phrasal verb which means to meet or find by accident. Hence, ‘come across to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Anant was telling a story about his most recent exploits when a tree branch break the living room window. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: when a tree branch break the living room window

answer: when a tree branch break the living room window

solution.content: when a tree branch break the living room window ‘Break’ must be replaced with ‘broke’. The given sentence is in Past Tense, so the verb will be used in the past form (broke). Hence, ‘when a tree branch broke the living room window’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We should / not make an noise / in the class. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: not make an noise ‘An noise’ must be replaced with ‘a noise’. Article ‘A’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound - (a conversation, a story). Hence, ‘not make a noise’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I was wish / to meet her / on her birthday. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: I was wish ‘I was wish’ must be replaced with ‘I wish’ as we generally use the expression ‘I wish’ to express wishes or desires. Hence, ‘I wish’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We have being / arranged the stay / for the guests at / a hillside resort. SSC CPO 04 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: We have being ‘We have being’ must be replaced with ‘We have’. The given sentence is in Present Perfect Tense and ‘Plural Sub. + have + V 3 (arranged)’ is the correct grammatical structure for it. Hence, ‘We have’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The students / are expected / to come/ in the right time. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: in the right time ‘In’ must be replaced with ‘at’. ‘At’ is used to indicate the specific time of an action. Hence, ‘at the right time’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We will / have been know the result / of the CAT exam by next week. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: of the CAT exam by next week

solution.content: have been know the result ‘Have been know’ must be replaced with ‘have known’. Future Perfect Tense is used when the time of completion of an event is given using the preposition ‘by’. ‘Will have + V 3 ’ is the correct grammatical structure for this sentence. Hence, ‘have known(V 3 ) the result’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He are very thirsty. / Give him / a little water to drink. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: He are very thirsty ‘Are’ must be replaced with ‘is’. According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘he’ is a singular subject that will take ‘is’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘He is very thirsty’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I am sure Helena / would passes / with flying colours. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: would passes ‘Modal verbs’ are auxiliary verbs(also called helping verbs) like can, will, could, shall, must, would, might, and should. However, after a modal verb, we generally use the first form of the verb (V 1 ). Hence, ‘would pass(V 1 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: One of their freighters, / a Neptune,/ will be leaving/ in two weeks. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: a Neptune Article ‘a’ must be replaced with article ‘the’. ‘Neptune’ mentioned in the given sentence is a specific ship and we generally use the definite article ‘the’ before any specific or particular noun. Hence, ‘the Neptune’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Identify the error in tense and choose the correct form of the verb in present tense from the following options. My teacher often forget the name of students. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: forgets ‘Simple Present Tense (Singular Sub. + V 1 -s/es + obj )’ will be used in the given sentence as it is used to state a habitual or repeated action. Hence, ‘forgets’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Roger went / to an United Kingdom / with his wife / to celebrate Christmas. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: to an United kingdom Article ‘an’ must be replaced with article ‘the’ as we generally use article ‘the’ with the name of the countries that are plural like The U.S.A, The Philippines etc. Hence, ‘to the United Kingdom’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I have a dog and a cow. / A dog is black / but the cow is / black and white. SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: I have a dog and a cow

solution.content: a dog is black Article ‘a’ must be replaced with ‘the’ as we generally use article ‘the’ when talking about specific or known things. Hence, ‘the dog is black’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: (1) He could / (2) be pass his exams / (3) if he studied harder. / (4) No error SSC CPO 05 / 10 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: 2 ‘Be pass’ must be replaced with ‘have passed’ as the given sentence is an example of a third conditional sentence and the correct grammatical structure for it is “If + Simple past(V 2 ) / past perfect(had + V 3 )…….. Would have + V 3 ”. Hence, ‘would have passed his exams’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error. The boy told his mother that he saw the most tall giraffe at the zoo. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: The boy told his mother that he saw the tallest giraffe at the zoo.
The boy told his mother that he saw the most taller giraffe at the zoo.
The boy told his mother that he saw the most tallest giraffe at the zoo.
The boy told his mother that he saw the more taller giraffe at the zoo.

answer: The boy told his mother that he saw the tallest giraffe at the zoo.

solution.content: The boy told his mother that he saw the tallest giraffe at the zoo.(Correct) (b) The boy told his mother that he saw the most taller giraffe at the zoo.(Incorrect Degree) (c) The boy told his mother that he saw the most tallest giraffe at the zoo.(Incorrect Degree) (d) The boy told his mother that he saw the more taller giraffe at the zoo.(Incorrect Degree)

question.content: Throughout my career as a journalist, / I covered many important stories and / interviewed numerous individuals, which allow me / to share important information and insights with my readers. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: to share important information and insights with my readers
I covered many important stories and
Throughout my career as a journalist,
interviewed numerous individuals, which allow me

answer: interviewed numerous individuals, which allow me

solution.content: interviewed numerous individuals, which allow me ‘Allow’ must be replaced with ‘allowed’. The given sentence is in past tense, so it must have the verb in the past form(allowed), not in the present form(allow). Hence, ‘which allowed me’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Harish told me / in the morning / that Gaurav will / come tomorrow. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: that Gaurav will The verb ‘Will’ must be replaced with ‘Would’ as the given sentence in the past tense, so we need to use the verb in past form. Hence, ‘Gaurav would’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: She performed / the dance routine / perfect, / impressing everyone. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: perfect ‘Perfect’ must be replaced with ‘perfectly’ as we generally use adverbs to modify the meaning of the verb(performed). Hence, ‘perfectly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: In America, / most of the people / can speak / the English well. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: the English well The definite article 'the' is not used before the name of language. Hence, 'English well’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: It is commonly believed / that Democracy is / the best form / of the government. SSC MTS 01 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: of the government Article ‘the’ must be removed as the word 'government' in the general sense refers to any form of government. It does not point towards any particular nation. Hence, ‘of government’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Al fiction is a constantly / evolving genre that gives us an peek / into the potential upsides and downsides / of intelligent machines. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: into a potential upside and downside
evolving genre that gives us a peek

answer: evolving genre that gives us a peek

solution.content: evolving genre that gives us a peek Article ‘A’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound - (a conversation, a story, a peek). Whereas, the article ‘An’ is used before the words starting from a vowel sound(an imminent danger, an apple). Hence ‘evolving genre that gives us a peek’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. If he will come early, we will leave on time . SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: will come ‘Will come’ must be replaced with ‘comes’. The given sentence is an example of the first conditional sentence and the correct grammatical structure is “if + simple present…….will +V 1 ”. Hence ‘comes’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Guard over / making mistakes / by carefully checking / the assigned task. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: Guard over ‘Guard over’ must be replaced with ‘guard against’ as the verb ‘guard’ is followed by the preposition ‘against’ when it means to protect something from harm or damage. Hence, ‘guard against’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Despite the setbacks and obstacles we faced, / our team rallied together and achieved our goals, / which teach us the importance of / teamwork, resilience, and determination. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: Despite the setbacks and obstacles we faced,
which teach us the importance of
our team rallied together and achieved our goals,

answer: which teach us the importance of

solution.content: which teach us the importance of The given sentence is in the past tense so it must have the verb in the past form(V 2 ) and not in the present form(teach). Hence, ‘which taught(V 2 ) us the importance of’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Choose the sentence that contains an error. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: The Mona Lisa is a famous painting by Leonardo da Vinci.
She is the only person who can speak five languages fluently.
He is a doctor who specialises in the treating rare diseases
I saw the movie that won the Academy Award for Best Picture.

answer: He is a doctor who specialises in the treating rare diseases

solution.content: He is a doctor who specialises in the treating rare diseases.(Incorrect) He is a doctor who specialises in treating rare diseases. (Correct) The definite article 'the' is not used before gerunds.

question.content: After I complete my training program / I will have been joining a team of astronauts / and preparing to / embark on a mission to Mars. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: I will have been joining a team of astronauts
embark on a mission to Mars
After I complete my training program

answer: I will have been joining a team of astronauts

solution.content: I will have been joining a team of astronauts ‘Will have been’ must be replaced with ‘will be’ as the given sentence is in the Future Continuous Tense and the correct grammatical structure is “Subject + will + be + V-ing”. Hence, ‘I will be joining a team of astronauts’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the bad. SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the worst.
Earlier, he was feeling good, but things took a turn for the bad.
Earlier, he was feeling well, but things took a turn for the ill.
Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the ill.

answer: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the worst.

solution.content: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the worst.(Correct) (b) Earlier, he was feeling good , but things took a turn for the bad.(Incorrect Word) (c) Earlier, he was feeling well , but things took a turn for the ill.(Incorrect Degree) (d) Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the ill .(Incorrect Word)

question.content: Why don't / you throw this / paper on the dust bin? SSC MTS 04 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: paper on the dust bin ‘On’ must be replaced with ‘in’. ‘In’ is used to indicate the location or position of something inside of something else. Preposition ‘On’ is used to indicate that something is touching the surface of something. Hence, ‘in’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A night alone / in a hotel / can be lonely prospect. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: can be lonely prospect Article ‘a’ must be used before ‘lonely prospect’ as the adjective ‘lonely’ describes a noun and we need to use an article before the adjective to indicate that it's a singular, countable noun. Hence, ‘can be a lonely prospect’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error. The new restaurant on Main Street is chea p than the old one . SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: is cheaper than We generally use a comparative degree before ‘than’ and the correct comparative degree of ‘cheap’ is ‘cheaper’. Hence, ‘is cheaper than’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. My relatives shall have reached Amritsar b y now . SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: shall ‘Shall’ must be replaced with ‘will’ as we generally use ‘will’ with ‘He/She/It/You/they’ or a noun and ‘shall’ with ‘I’ and ‘we’ only. Hence, ‘will’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: They will start their journey after the breakfast. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: after the breakfast ‘The’ must be removed before ‘breakfast’ as we generally do not use any article before the names of meals(breakfast, dinner, lunch, etc). Hence, ‘after breakfast’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: They had been dancing / for an hour / when our dance teacher/ had arrived. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: had arrived 'When + Simple Past Tense(Subject + V 2 )' is used to indicate the time of occurrence of an event that started in the past. Therefore, ‘had’ must be removed from this part. Hence, 'arrived' is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. For an all-too-brief period between the late 1980s and the late 2000s, a world was characterised by convergence. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: a world was ‘A world’ must be replaced with ‘the world’ as we generally use article ‘the’ with a specific place or thing. Hence, ‘the world was’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Shelley and Keats are great writers, but I prefer the last. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content:
the last ‘ The last’ must be replaced with ‘the latter’ as the wor ‘latter’ is
used to refer to the second of two things or people. Hence, ‘the latter’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Jaya said that she will become topper in her class. SSC MTS 05 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: she will become topper ‘Will’ must be replaced with ‘would’ as the given sentence is in past tense so we need to use the past form of the verb. Hence, ‘she would become topper’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This is the first time / I ate such / a tasty cake. SSC MTS 06 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

question.content: Existentialism has a reputation for being angst-ridden and gloomy mostly because of its emphasis on pondering the meaningless of existence. SSC MTS 06 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

question.content: I want to give you / an information about / the missing necklace. SSC MTS 06 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: an information about Article ‘an’ must be removed as we do not use indefinite articles (a/an) before uncountable nouns such as information, luggage, evidence, furniture. Hence, ‘information about’ is the most appropriate answer.
D ‘Fells’ must be replaced with ‘fell’ as the correct past form of the verb ‘fall’ is ‘fell’. Hence, ‘Look, he fell!’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: My younger daughter, / Kanu prefer / dark chocolate / to yoghurt. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: I saw a movie that was directed by Steven Spielberg

answer: He is an lawyer who works for a prestigious law firm.

solution.content: He is an lawyer who works for a prestigious law firm. Article ‘an’ must be replaced with ‘a’ as we generally use article ‘a’ before the words starting with a consonant sound. Similarly, in the given sentence, the noun ‘lawyer’ starts with a consonant sound. Hence, ‘a lawyer’ is the most appropriate answer.

two is coming ‘Two is coming’ must be replaced with ‘Two comes’. We generally use Simple Present Tense(Singular Sub. + V-s/es) to state a fact or universal truth. Hence, ‘two comes’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This scripture / has been /translated in / seventy languages. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

question.content: She was writing / a letter to her grandmother / when the power / gone out. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: gone out 'When + Simple Past Tense' is used to indicate the time of occurrence of an event that started in the past. 'Subject + V 2 ' is the correct grammatical structure for this sentence. Hence, 'went out(V 2 )' is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Mr Sharma would have left / the station / by this time / tomorrow. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: Mr sharma would have left ‘Would’ must be replaced with ‘will’ as we generally use future perfect tense (will/shall + have + V 3 ) to express an action which will be completed before a certain point in the future. Hence, ‘Mr sharma will have left’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The viable of life / depends on a pair of conflicting realities. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: The viable of life Adjective ‘viable’ must be replaced with the noun ‘viability’ as we need to use a specific noun after the article ‘the.’ Hence, ‘the viability of life’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I shall be playing for four hours. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

question.content: I had / a bad habit of / waking up / lately. SSC MTS 08 / 09 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: lately Lately means recently while ‘late’ means after the usual or expected time. Adverb ‘late’ is the correct choice here as it denotes the person’s habit of waking up after the expected time in the past. Hence, ‘late’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: As they driven through the dark, twisting lane / down which they had walked earlier, Lucius heard / the whistling of the night air in his ears. SSC MTS 11 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: down which they had walked earlier, Lucius heard
the whistling of the night air in his ears.

answer: As they driven through the dark, twisting lane

solution.content: As they driven through the dark, twisting lane If two actions took place in the past then the 1st action must be in the Past perfect tense(Had + V 3 - walked) and the 2nd action must be in the Simple Past tense(V 2 ). However, the V 2 form of ‘drive’ is ‘drove’. Hence, ‘as they drove(V 2 ) through the dark, twisting lane’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The platinum is a precious metal. SSC MTS 11 / 09 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: The platinum Article ‘the’ must be removed as the definite article 'the' is not used before the name of materials like Gold, Silver, Platinum etc. Hence, ‘platinum’ is the most appropriate answer.

solution.content: most off ‘Off’ must be replaced with ‘of’ as ‘Off’ is usually used as a preposition to indicate separation (going away from something) or disconnection. Preposition ‘Of’ is used to indicate something being part of something. Therefore, ‘most of’ is the most appropriate answer.

This is the oldest standing structure of Chola architecture in India. ‘Eldest’ must be replaced with ‘oldest’. We use superlative degree 'eldest' for blood relations of the same generation or lower generation & 'oldest' for something that was created first

question.content: Parts of the given sentence have been underlined. One of them contains an error. The underlined parts are given as options with some changes. question.content: Choose the sentence that contains an error. SSC MTS 12 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. We think of the past history of the world as fixed but of the future as undecided and open to a wealth off possibilities. SSC MTS 12 / 09 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

invited to lunch When we talk about a meal(lunch/dinner/breakfast) as a special event, we use the article 'the' before the meal. For ex- the lunch with the president of India.

question.content: The investigation conducting by the research team / yielded statistically significant results / providing substantial evidence / to support the hypothesis. SSC CHSL 08 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

options.text: The investigation conducting by the research team

answer: The investigation conducting by the research team

solution.content: The investigation conducting by the research team. A participle phrase is a group of words which includes a past participle form (V 3 ) and functions as an adjective, providing additional information about the subject. Similarly, In the given sentence, the participle phrase "conducted(V 3 ) by the team" provides additional information about the subject ‘the investigation’. Hence, 'the investigation conducted by the research team' is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: It was Ravi, not his friends, / who were shouting / at late hours last night. SSC CHSL 08 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

options.text: It was Ravi, not his friends,

solution.content: who were shouting ‘Were’ must be replaced with ‘was.’ According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. ‘Ravi’ is a singular subject that will take ‘was’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘who was shouting’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Washington Irving's writing career started at / the tender age of nineteen when he joined / his brother Peter's newspaper The Morning Chronicle / as journalist. SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: his brother Peter's newspaper The Morning Chronicle
Washington Irving's writing career started at
the tender age of nineteen when he joined

solution.content: as journalist Article ‘a’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound (a conversation, a story). Therefore, article ‘a’ must be used before the word ‘journalist’. Hence, ‘as a journalist’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: There was a saying that they’re their own enemies with negligble reason to be shared. SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: negligble ‘Negligible’ is the correct spelling.

question.content: Can you make / sure you have / a correct address / before you start driving? SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: a correct address ‘’A correct address’ must be replaced with ‘the correct address’ as we generally use article ‘the’ before definite or particular nouns. Similarly, the given sentence is talking about a particular address. Hence, ‘the correct address’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The food container / is not enough big to meet / the demands of the affected people. SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: is not enough big to meet
the demands of the affected people

answer: is not enough big to meet

solution.content: is not enough big to meet ‘Enough big’ must be replaced with ‘big enough’ as ‘enough’ is a special adverb and always used after the adjective(‘big’ in the given sentence). Hence, ‘is not big enough to meet’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: By virtue off / the power given to the leader / the followers accepted his decision SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

options.text: the power given to the leader

solution.content: By virtue off ‘By virtue of’ is the correct preposition and it is used to provide reason. Hence, ‘by virtue of’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The team of scientists / were conducting / experiments to test / their hypothesis SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content: were conducting According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. ‘Team’ is a singular subject that will take ‘was’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘was conducting’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This region / was struck by unusual / wave of violence / last year. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: was struck by unusual Article ‘An’ is used before the words starting from a vowel sound(an imminent danger, an apple). Therefore, article ‘an’ must be used before the word ‘unusual’. Hence, ‘was struck by an unusual’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: With reference of your letter, / the organisation wishes to hire you / for the security services. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: the organisation wishes to hire you

solution.content: With reference of your letter ‘Of’ must be replaced with ‘to’ as ‘with reference to’ is the correct phrase which means about or concerning(something). Hence, ‘with reference to your letter’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: It is imperative in understanding / the rising importance of artificial intelligence / in the public sector to increase the efficacy / and impact of the work done for public welfare. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

options.text: the rising importance of artificial intelligence
and impact of the work done for public welfare.
in the public sector to increase the efficacy

solution.content: It is imperative in understanding ‘In understanding’ must be replaced with ‘to understand’. We generally use the phrase ‘it is imperative/important + to + V 1 ’ when the infinitive(to + V 1 ) tells us what is important. Hence, ‘it is imperative to understand(V 1 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The soldier met / a fearless death / fighting on behalf at his country. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

options.text: fighting on behalf at his country

answer: fighting on behalf at his country

solution.content: fighting on behalf at his country ‘On behalf at his country’ must be replaced with ‘on behalf of his country’. The phrase ‘on behalf of’ is used to indicate that someone is acting or speaking for another person, group or organisation. Hence, ‘fighting on behalf of his country’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Choose the sentence that contains an error. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

options.text: I need to buy an new iPhone.
The cat sat on the windowsill
She is the best singer in the choir.
He is an artist who paints landscapes.

answer: I need to buy an new iPhone.

solution.content: I need to buy an new iPhone.(Incorrect Article) I need to buy a new iPhone.(Correct) Article ‘A’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound - (a conversation, a story).

question.content: The man / is a / social animal. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: The man No article is used when a noun is used in the general sense. Therefore, article ‘the’ must be removed before ‘man’. Hence, ‘man’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The poor undergoes / several problems in life / that could be / solved with money. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: The poor undergoes An adjective represents the whole class of people when article ‘the’ is used before it. Similarly, ‘the poor’ represents all the poor people. We always use a plural verb after such adjectives. Hence, ‘The poor undergo’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

options.text: I could not find it anywhere.

answer: I could not find it anywhere.

solution.content: I could not find it anywhere.(Correct) (a) He ate the sweets greedy .(‘Greedily’ will be used) (c) I haven't got none.(‘Have’ will be used) (d) He is much weak .(‘Weaker’ will be used)

question.content: He speaks pleasantly / with her yesterday / evening but not today. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content: He speaks pleasantly ‘Speaks’ must be replaced with ‘spoke’ as we generally use ‘simple past tense(V 2 )’ to describe actions, events, or states that occurred and were completed in the past. Similarly, in the sentence, the action was completed yesterday. Hence, ‘he spoke(V 2 ) pleasantly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Hurray! Here is the toy / what I was looking for / as my birthday gift. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: what I was looking for ‘What’ must be replaced with ‘that’ as when we introduce a relative clause that provides more information about a noun, we typically use "that" or "which" instead of "what". Hence, ‘that i was looking for’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The politician was accused / of accepting bribes / and lied about it / to the public. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: and lied about it According to the ‘Rule of Parallelism’, two or more verbs must be in the same form if they are connected with one another. Similarly, in the given sentence, ‘and’ connects two verbs 'accepting(V ing )’ and ‘lied’. Therefore, ‘lying(V ing )’ must be used in place of ‘lied’. Hence, ‘and lying about it’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The news / is / very good / to be true. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: very good ‘Very’ must be replaced with ‘too’ as ‘too good to be true’ is an idiom that means something is so positive or favorable. Hence, ‘too good’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This boy / is cleverest / of all / in the class. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: is cleverest We generally use article ‘the’ with a superlative degree i.e. cleverest. Hence, ‘is the cleverest’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Identify the error in the use of preposition in the given sentence and select the correct option. Her family lost their way on Daman. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.content: in The preposition ‘on’ must be replaced with ‘in’ as ‘In’ is used to indicate location or position within a place or area. Similarly, in the sentence, ‘Daman’ is a location and we need to use the preposition ‘in’ before it. Hence, ‘in’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the sentence that has a grammatical error. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content: Rama can bowl fastly .(Incorrect) Rama can bowl fast.(Correct) ‘Fast’ is already an adverb. We can not add ‘ly’ to it.

question.content: I brought / an apple from a place you recommended / me earlier. SSC CHSL 14 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content: a place you recommended The article ‘the’ is used to refer to specific or particular nouns & articles ‘a/an’ are used for non-specific or non-particular nouns. For example, if someone says, "Let's buy the book," it means a specific book but if someone says, "Let's buy a book," it means any book rather than a specific book. Similarly, the given sentence talks about a specific place. Hence, ‘the place you recommended’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A crocodile / was swimming / in a river. SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: An old man whom / we met while coming back / from our college lives / at my uncle’s Place. SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (1st Shift)

solution.content: An old man whom ‘An old man’ must be replaced with ‘the old man’. The article ‘the’ is used to refer to specific or particular nouns. Similarly, the given sentence talks about a particular old man. Hence, ‘the old man whom’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct version of the following sentence. He was youngest than his brother. SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

options.text: He was younger than his brother.
He was youngest to his brother.
He was too young than his brother
He was young to his brother.

answer: He was younger than his brother.

solution.content: He was younger than his brother.(Correct) (b) He was youngest to his brother.(Incorrect Degree and Word) (c) He was too young than his brother.(Incorrect Word and Degree) (d) He was young to his brother.(Incorrect Degree and Word)

question.content: When I was in 5th grade, / I use to / ride on my / red bicycle SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.content: I use to ‘Use to’ must be replaced with the semi-modal ‘used to’ as we generally use it to state a habitual action from the past. Hence, ‘I used to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A owl was / hooting throughout / the night. SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content: A owl was Article ‘a’ must be replaced with article ‘an’. Article ‘A’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound - (a conversation, a story). Whereas, the article ‘An’ is used before the words starting from a vowel sound(an imminent danger, an apple). Hence, ‘an owl was’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: They were laid / in the sun / the entire morning / till Sudharshan came. SSC CHSL 17 / 08 / 2023 (4th Shift)

solution.content:
They were laid The given sentence is an example of passive voice of Past Continuous Tense and the subject ‘they’ is plural. ‘Plural Sub. + were + V ing ‘ is the correct grammatical structure for this
sentence. ‘Laid’ must be replaced with ‘lying’ as ‘lying’ means resting in a horizontal position. Hence, ‘they were lying’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Neetu have been / waiting for me / since 10 o'clock / in the morning. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

solution.content: Neetu have been ‘Have’ must be replaced with ‘has.’ According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘Neetu’ is a singular subject that will take ‘has’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘Neetu has been’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

options.text: The participants of the competition are waiting for their turn curiously.
The participants of the competition has been waiting for their turn curiously.
A participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously.
The participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously.

answer: The participants of the competition are waiting for their turn curiously.

solution.content:
The participants of the competition are waiting for their turn curiously.(Correct) (b) The participants of the competition has been waiting for their turn curiously. (Incorrect Tense) (c) A participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously. (Incorrect Article and Verb)
(d) The participants of the competition is waiting for their turn curiously. (Incorrect Helping Verb)

question.content: After knowing truth, / the jury took the right decision / in the case. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

options.text: The jury took the right decision

solution.content: after knowing truth Article ‘the’ will be used before ‘truth’ as we generally use the definite article ‘the’ with a specific noun. Hence, ‘after knowing the truth’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Darshan wished he hadn't / went to the theme park / in the first place. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

solution.content: went to the theme park If two actions took place in the past then the 1st action must be in the Past perfect tense(Had + V 3 ) and the 2nd action must be in the Simple Past tense(V 2 ). However, the V 3 form of ‘go’ is ‘gone’. Hence, ‘gone to the theme park’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The availability of funds will be / ensured if they all tried to / submit the proposals on time. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

options.text: The availability of funds will be
ensured if they all tried to

answer: ensured if they all tried to

solution.content: ensured if they all tried to ‘Tried’ must be replaced with ‘try’ as the given sentence is an example of the first conditional sentence. According to it, when the main clause is in the future tense, the verb in the subordinate clause (the part after "if") should be in the present tense. Hence, ‘ensured if they all try to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct statement from among the given options. A. It is a nice party. I am enjoying the party. B. It is a party. I am enjoying an party. C. It is party. I am enjoying a party. D. It is the party. I am enjoying an party. SSC CGL 14 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: A. It is a nice party. I am enjoying the party. (a) D. It is the party. I am enjoying an party. (Incorrect Article) (b) C. It is party. I am enjoying a party. (Incorrect Article) (c) B. It is a party. I am enjoying an party. (Incorrect Article)

question.content: I think Jeremy will not / have save enough money/ by the time / the year ends. SSC CGL 17 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

solution.content: have save enough money ‘Will have/shall have’ always takes the third form (past participle) of the verb. However, the past participle form of ‘save’ is ‘saved’. Hence, ‘have saved enough money’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. A. It is a old uniform but a memorable thing for me. B. It is old uniform but a memorable thing for me. C. It is the old uniform but memorable thing for me. D. It is an old uniform but a memorable thing for me. SSC CGL 17 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: D. It is an old uniform but a memorable thing for me.(Correct) (b) C. It is the old uniform but memorable thing for me. (Incorrect Article) (c) B. It is old uniform but a memorable thing for me. (Article is missing) (d) A. It is a old uniform but a memorable thing for me. (Incorrect Article)

question.content: Identify the sentence that correctly uses the indefinite article. SSC CGL 18 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

options.text: She purchased a apple in the market with me.
She purchased an apple in the market with me.
She purchased apple in the market with me.
She purchase a apple in the market with me.

answer: She purchased an apple in the market with me.

solution.content: She purchased an apple in the market with me. Article ‘A’ is used before the words starting from a consonant sound - (a European, a story). Whereas, the article ‘An’ is used before the words starting from a vowel sound(an indian artist, an apple). Going through the options, the sentence given in option ‘b’ has the most appropriate use of the indefinite article.

question.content: I can't talk right now. / I am being really busy. / I'll call you later. SSC CGL 18 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

solution.content: I am being really busy Use of ‘being’ is superfluous as we need to use only simple present tense in the given sentence. Hence, ‘I am really busy’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The following sentence has been divided into three segments, A, B, C. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the segment that contains the error, form the given options. If you don’t find any error, mark ‘No error’ as your answer. Aniket lives

solution.content: in the small apartment Article ‘the’ must be replaced with ‘a’ as ‘small apartment’ mentioned in the given sentence is not specific and we generally use the indefinite article ‘a’ before a non-specific noun. Hence, ‘in a small apartment’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The present-century threats to our environment, / which include interfering species, ailments, pollution and / a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril. SSC CGL 18 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

options.text: which include interfering species, ailments, pollution and
The present-century threats to our environment
a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril

answer: a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril

solution.content: a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril. 'Were' must be replaced with 'are' as the given sentence states an action in present tense, clearly indicated by the term 'The present-century'. So we need to use present continuous tense(are + V 1 -ing). Hence, ' are putting wildlife populations at peril' is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: My mother said / that Ben will done / the assignment / today. SSC CGL 18 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: that Ben will done ‘Modal verbs’ are auxiliary verbs(also called helping verbs) like can, will, could, shall, must, would, might, and should. However, after a modal verb, we generally use the first form of the verb (V 1 ). Hence, ‘that Ben will do(V 1 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Mr. Ram Kumar, the cashier are / on temporary withdrawal / from service. SSC CGL 18 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

options.text: Mr. Ram Kumar, the cashier are

answer: Mr. Ram Kumar, the cashier are

solution.content: Mr. Ram Kumar, the cashier are ‘Are’ must be replaced with ‘is’. According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, a singular subject always takes a singular verb and a plural subject always takes a plural verb. In the given sentence, ‘Mr. Ram Kumar’ is a singular subject that will take ‘is’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘Mr. Ram Kumar, the cashier is’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC CGL 19 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

options.text: The rider who met with a accident was not wearing a helmet, the police said.
The rider who met with an accident was not wearing an helmet, the police said.
A rider who met with the accident was not wearing the helmet, an police said.
The rider who met with the accident was not wearing a helmet, the police said.

answer: The rider who met with the accident was not wearing a helmet, the police said.

solution.content: The rider who met with the accident was not wearing a helmet, the police said.(Correct) (a) The rider who met with a accident was not wearing a helmet, the police said. (Incorrect Article) (b) The rider who met with an accident was not wearing an helmet, the police said. (Incorrect Article) (c) A rider who met with the accident was not wearing the helmet, an police said. (Incorrect Article)

question.content: "Do you want to join us for lunch?" / "I'm sorry / my physics class will start at 1 p.m. / and doesn't finish till 3 p.m." SSC CGL 19 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

options.text: my physics class will start at 1 p.m.
Do you want to join us for lunch?

answer: my physics class will start at 1 p.m.

solution.content: my physics class will start at 1 p.m. ‘Will start’ must be replaced with ‘starts’ as we generally use simple present tense(V 1 -s/es) to indicate routines that happen regularly. Hence, ‘starts(V 1 -s)’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Sky appears blue / as it absorbs / all colours and /reflects only blue. SSC CGL 19 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

solution.content: Sky appears blue ‘Sky appears’ must be replaced with ‘The sky appears’ as we generally use definite article (the) before a specific or particular noun. Hence, ‘The sky appears blue’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A celestial body or astronomical object is / a naturally occurring physical thing, association, / or configuration that happens in the visible universe. SSC CGL 19 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

options.text: A celestial body or astronomical object is
or configuration that happens in the visible universe
a naturally occurring physical thing, association

solution.content: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. The Dutta company has not being making new school bags since the lockdown commenced . SSC CGL 19 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: Being ‘Being’ must be replaced with ‘been’ as we generally use the conjunction ‘since’ in the Present Perfect Continuous Tense to denote a point of time in the past. ‘Singular Sub. + has + been + V-ing’ is the correct grammatical structure. Hence, ‘has not been’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The following sentence has been divided into three segments, A, B, C. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the segment that contains the error, from the given options. If you don't find any error, mark 'No error' as your answer. It was

options.text: / he saw a movie in a theatre

solution.content: By a chance Article ‘a‘ must be removed as ‘by chance’ is the correct phrase. ‘By chance’ means accidentally, without plan or intent. Hence, ‘by chance’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: One of these / boxes have / the portrait / of the heiress. SSC CGL 20 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

solution.content: boxes have ‘Have’ must be replaced with ‘has.’ According to the “Subject-Verb Agreement Rule”, ‘One of/ Each of/ Most of/ Either of + Plural Subject + Singular verb’ is grammatically the correct structure. Hence, ‘boxes has’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: You can fool some of the people all the time, and all the people some of the time; but you cannot fool all the people all the time. SSC CGL 20 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

options.text: You can fool some of the people all the time
and all the people some of the time
but you cannot fool all the people all the time.

solution.content: No error The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Hardik's horoscope says / that the stars / will be exercised/ a benign influence on his life. SSC CGL 20 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

options.text: a benign influence on his life

solution.content: will be exercised ‘Will be exercised’ must be replaced with ‘will exercise’ as we generally use active voice when the subject is the doer of the action. In the given sentence, the subject(‘stars’) is the doer of the action(exercise an influence). Hence, ‘will exercise’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. A.Today is sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. B. Today is a sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. C. Today is the sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. D. Today is sixth day of our workshop. All participants are highly enthusiastic. SSC CGL 20 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

solution.content:
C. Today is the sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. (Correct)
A. Today is sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. (Article is missing) B. Today is a sixth day of our workshop. All the participants are highly enthusiastic. (Incorrect Article) D. Today is sixth day of our workshop. All participants are highly enthusiastic. (Article is missing)

question.content: Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error. I had gone to Siliguri before I go to Raiganj . SSC CGL 20 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: go ‘Go’ must be replaced with ‘went’. If two actions took place in the past then the 1st action must be in the Past perfect tense(Had + V 3 ) and the 2nd action must be in the Simple Past tense(V 2 ). Hence, ‘went(V 2 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He will return in a hour. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

solution.content: in a Article ‘a’ must be replaced with ‘an’ as article ‘An’ is used before the words starting from a vowel sound(an Indian artist, an apple, an hour). Hence, ‘in an’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Binay said that /he is coming / from /his village, Jaygarh. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

solution.content: he is coming ‘Is’ must be replaced with ‘was’ as the given sentence is an example of Indirect tense in the past tense. So, the correct grammatical structure is ‘Singular Sub. + was + V-ing’. Hence, ‘he was coming’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: If things were not going to be normal / after the pandemic, mankind will / have to accept the New Normal. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

options.text: have to accept the New Normal
If things were not going to be normal

answer: If things were not going to be normal

solution.content: If things were not going to be normal ‘Were’ must be replaced with ‘are’ as the given sentence is an example of the mixed conditional sentence and the correct grammatical structure is “If + Present Tense…….will +V 1 ”. Hence ‘If things are not going to be normal’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This will be most difficult of / the adjustments we have to make / because we have been used to / spending a lot on guests. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (3rd shift)

options.text: the adjustments we have to make
This will be most difficult of
because we have been used to

answer: This will be most difficult of

solution.content: This will be most difficult of ‘Superlative degree ’ denotes the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses the highest or a very high degree of quality of a thing, person etc. For example, most, best, worst, greatest, etc. However, we always place the definite article ‘the’ before any superlative adjective. Hence, ‘this will be the most difficult of’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Select the grammatically correct sentence. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

options.text: The decision to change a hospital saved an life of the daughter of the doctor.
The decision to change the hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor.
The decision to change an hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor.
A decision to change a hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor.

answer: The decision to change the hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor.

solution.content: The decision to change the hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor.(Correct) (a) The decision to change a hospital saved an life of the daughter of the doctor .(Incorrect Article) (c) The decision to change an hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor .(Incorrect Article) (d) A decision to change a hospital saved the life of the daughter of the doctor .(Incorrect Article)

question.content: If / it will rain, / we will have / a tough time. SSC CGL 21 / 07 / 2023 (4th shift)

solution.content: it will rain ‘Will rain’ must be replaced with ‘rains’ as the given sentence is an example of the first conditional sentence and the correct grammatical structure is “if + simple present……will +V 1 ”. Hence ‘rains’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I am sure that / the postman would be / coming shortly / to deliver the letter. SSC CGL 24 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

solution.content: the postman would be ‘Would be’ must be replaced with ‘will be’. Modal ‘would’ is used to talk about the future as seen from the past. Modal ‘will’ is used to talk about the future as seen from the present moment. As the first part of the sentence is in Present Tense, modal ‘will’ will be used. Hence, ‘the postman will be’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Maruti likes / adventure / stories, especially / an adventures of Tarzan. SSC CGL 24 / 07 / 2023 (1st shift)

solution.content: an adventures of Tarzan ‘An’ must be replaced with ‘the. The word "adventures" is plural, so it should not be preceded by the singular article "an”. We generally use the definite article with a specific noun or a particular noun (adventures of Tarzan). Hence, ‘the adventures of Tarzan’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The receptionist asked if Diya / will take a seat and / wait for the boss to call her in. SSC CGL 24 / 07 / 2023 (2nd shift)

options.text: wait for the boss to call her in

strong before you know it Use of the positive degree adjective ‘strong’ is incorrect as we

question.content: As she kept walking to me, my heart skipped a beat . SSC CHSL 09 / 06 / 2022 (Morning)

options.text: As she kept walking within me, my heart skipped a beat.
As she kept walking from me, my heart skipped a beat
As she kept into me, my heart skipped a beat.
As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat.

answer: As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat.

solution.content: As she kept walking towards me, my heart skipped a beat. (Correct) (a) As she kept walking within me, my heart skipped a beat. (Incorrect preposition) (b) As she kept walking from me, my heart skipped a beat.(Incorrect preposition) (c) As she kept into me, my heart skipped a beat.(Incorrect preposition)

question.content: There were more than thirty delegates who attend the training programme last summer. SSC CHSL 09 / 06 / 2022 (Evening)

options.text: There are more than thirty delegates who attend the training programme last summer
There were more than thirty delegates who attends the training programme last summer.
There was more than thirty delegates who attend the training programme last summer
There were more than thirty delegates who attended the training programme last summer.

answer: There were more than thirty delegates who attended the training programme last summer.

solution.content: There were more than thirty delegates who attended the training programme last summer. (Correct) (a) There are more than thirty delegates who attend the training programme last summer.(Incorrect tense) (b) There were more than thirty delegates who attends the training programme last summer. (Incorrect tense) (c) There was more than thirty delegates who attend the training programme last summer.( Incorrect verb)

question.content: As soon as we went for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn. SSC CHSL 10 / 06 / 2022 (Morning)

options.text: As soon as we were going for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.
As soon as we went for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.
As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.
As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.

answer: As soon as we went for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.

solution.content: As soon as we went for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Correct) (a) As soon as we were going for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect word- The past form of dig is dug) (c) As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia digged a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect word - The past form of dig is dug) (d) As soon as we gone for an afternoon siesta, my pet rabbit Tia dug a huge hole right in the middle of the lawn.(Incorrect verb)

question.content: It was / the very well-directed film / and we enjoyed it. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: the very well-directed film The ‘film’ mentioned in the given sentence is not specific and we generally use the indefinite article ‘a’ before a non-specific noun. Hence, ‘a very well directed’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: If the economy fails / this year it reflect badly / on the government. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: this year it reflect badly The given sentence is a conditional sentence which has a futuristic sense so the verb used must be in the future tense(will). Hence, ‘it will reflect badly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We stayed / in Jim’s flat / during he was / on holiday. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: during he was ‘When’ is used for talking about the time at which something happens or happened. The given sentence talks about the time at which Jim was on holiday. Hence, ‘when he was’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Do you / recall to meet / her at the party / last night? SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: recall to meet The given sentence will have a bare infinitive (without the preposition ‘to’). Hence, ‘recall meeting’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: It is not worth / having the trouble / to write to him / as he never replies. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: having the trouble ‘Taking the trouble’ is grammatically the correct phrase for the given sentence. Hence, ‘having’ will be replaced with ‘taking’ & ‘taking the trouble’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This is / too grave sin / to be / pardoned. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: too grave sin We will put the indefinite article ‘a’ before ‘sin’ as the sin is not-specific. Hence, ‘too grave a sin’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The unseasonal rain/ caused a lot of damage/ to the crops. SSC CGL 11 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: How many / eggs were put / into the basket? SSC CGL 12 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: We have / not met / some of our friends / since six months. SSC CGL 12 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content:
since six months ‘For’ refers to a specific period of time or a numerical value of time, for example for 2 years, for 4 weeks, for 3 days, etc.
However, in the given question, the period of time is 6 months. Hence, ‘for six months’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The policeman asked / many people but / no one was knowing / how the accident happened. SSC CGL 12 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: no one was knowing The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in its past form(V 2 ) and not in the past continuous form(was +V-ing). Hence, ‘no one knew(V 2 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This question / is quite too / simple for me / to answer. SSC CGL 13 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: is quite too The use of ‘quite’ is irrelevant in the grammatical context of the given sentence as ‘too…to’ is a fixed pair. Hence, ‘is too simple for me to answer’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: You should / have respond / to my query / sooner. SSC CGL 13 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: have respond “Have + V 3 (third form of the verb)” is grammatically the correct structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘have responded( V 3 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The manager said, “Could you please confirm me whether you have received all the items that you had ordered?” SSC CGL 13 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: confirm me whether you The use of the pronoun ‘me’ is grammatically incorrect in the given sentence so it must be removed. Hence, ‘confirm whether you’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We thought / there was a good idea / to wear snow boots / before we stepped out. SSC CGL 13 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: there was a good idea ‘Idea’ in the given sentence is a singular subject and for it, we will use ‘it’ as a singular pronoun and not ‘there’. Hence, ‘it was a good idea’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: There have been /three breaks-in /in our society/ this month. SSC CGL 18 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: three breaks-in ‘Break-in’ is a phrasal verb which means to enter a building by force, usually in order to steal something. However, the given sentence talks about three attempts so we will use the plural form of ‘break-in’. Hence, ‘three break-ins’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He / can have been / more polite / to her. SSC CGL 18 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: can have been We will replace ‘can’ with ‘could’ because ‘could’ sounds more polite than ‘can’. Hence, ‘could have been’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Aarav’s mother / speaks four languages / fluently. SSC CGL 18 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: Several minutes passed / before she returned / carry milk / for the dog. SSC CGL 19 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: carry milk We will replace ‘carry’ with ‘carrying’ in the last part of the given sentence as it requires a gerund(V-ing). Hence, ‘carrying milk’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The Taj Mahal / is one of / the most beautiful / creation in the world. SSC CGL 19 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: creation in the world According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement Rule ”, ‘ One of/ Each of/ Most of/ None of + Plural Subject” is grammatically the correct structure. Similarly, the given sentence will have ‘creations’ as a plural subject. Hence, ‘creations in the world’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This park is / the largest bird sanctuary / in the State. SSC CGL 19 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: I was angry / on myself / for making / such a silly mistake. SSC CGL 19 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: on myself ‘Angry with someone’ is grammatically the correct phrase for the given sentence. Hence, ‘angry with myself’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Mrs. Verma refused / the second helping / of ice cream. SSC CGL 20 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: Get up from your place / slow, and / turn around! SSC CGL 20 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: slow, and The given sentence needs an ‘adverb’. Hence, ‘slowly’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We bought / two dozens / mangoes from / the market SSC CGL 20 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: two dozens We never write ‘dozens’ if we are using a numerical amount like two, three, etc. before it. For example, ‘two dozens of bananas’ is incorrect but ‘three dozen of mangoes’ is correct. Similarly, the given sentence has ‘two’ as a numerical value. Hence, ‘two dozen’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: You and I / have submitted / your work / on time. SSC CGL 21 / 04 / 2022 (Morning)

solution.content: your work ‘Our’ is the possessive form of ‘we’ and it means something belonging to us(more than a single person). Similarly in the given sentence, the work belongs to both the persons and not to a single person. Hence, ‘our work’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: I do not / like to read / these kind / of novels. SSC CGL 21 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: these kind ‘This’ and ‘kind’ are in singular form whereas ‘These’ and ‘kinds’ are in plural form. Hence,‘these kinds’ will be grammatically correct for the given sentence.

question.content: Shall / we go / for walking / in the park? SSC CGL 21 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: for walking When we use verbs like walk, talk, ride, drink, etc. as nouns, we put the indefinite article ‘a’ before them as per their sound. For example, we had a talk, let's go for a drive, etc. Hence, ‘for a walk’ is the most appropriate answer.
