question.content: Among you and me / she is quite rude / to the boy. SSC CGL 21 / 04 / 2022 (Afternoon)

solution.content: Among you and me We use ‘among’ for more than two persons and ‘between’ for two persons. However, there are two persons mentioned in the given sentence. Hence, ‘Between you and me’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I find that / I get myself tired / very easily / these days. SSC CGL 21 / 04 / 2022 (Evening)

solution.content: I get myself tired The use of the reflexive pronoun ‘myself’ is irrelevant according to the grammatical context of the sentence so it will be removed. Hence, ‘I get tired’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: If you have / remained calm / you could have / saved the situation. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: If you have If you have “ If + had + V 3 …. could have + V 3 ( third form of the verb )” is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘If you had’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I will spend / my rest of remaining / life in my / native village. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: my rest of remaining We cannot use ‘rest’ & ‘remaining’ together in a sentence as it becomes the case of superfluousness(not necessary). Hence, ‘remaining’ will be removed from the sentence & ‘the rest of my life’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: We yet / have time / to catch / the bus. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: We yet ‘Still’ means starting in the past and continuing until now. However, ‘still’ generally comes before a verb in the present perfect form(has/have) and ‘yet’ usually comes at the end of the sentence. Similarly in the given sentence, the time for catching the bus has started in the past and continued till now. Hence, ‘We still’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This dog seems / to be very ferocious, / otherwise, / it is harmless. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: Otherwise ‘Otherwise‘ is a conjunction that means apart from that. However, ‘But’ is also a conjunction that is used for introducing an idea that contrasts with or is different from what has just been said. Similarly in the given sentence, the statement that the dog is harmless contrasts with its characteristic of being ferocious(violent). Hence, ‘But’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The girl lay down / on the bed / besides her mother / and went to sleep. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: besides her mother ‘Besides’ means ‘in addition to something’ & ‘Beside’ means ‘at the side of, or next to somebody/something’. However, the given sentence states that the girl lay down on the bed next to her mother and went to sleep. Hence, ‘beside her mother’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He went / to the bed / with a / slight fever. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: to the bed We generally use the phrases ‘go to bed’, ‘gone to bed’ or ‘went to bed’. Hence, we will remove the definite article ‘the’ from the given sentence and ‘went to bed’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The city turned out / to be very / different to what / he had expected. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: different to what There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘to’ after ‘different’ must be replaced with ‘from’ because ‘different’ generally takes the preposition ‘from’ with it. Hence, ‘different from what’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Your name / precedes before / mine / in the list. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: precedes before We cannot write ‘precedes’ and ‘before’ together in a sentence as they have similar meanings & that will become a case of superfluousness (not necessary). Hence, ‘before’ must be removed from the sentence to make it grammatically correct.

question.content: You should / avail this opportunity / to demonstrate / your skills. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: avail this opportunity ‘Avail’ always takes the preposition ‘of’ and a reflexive pronoun(myself, yourself, ourselves, etc.) in accordance with the given subject(You). Hence, ‘avail yourself of this opportunity’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He was unable / to help me because / he had been failed / to arrange the money. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: he had been failed The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in its simple past form(failed) and not in the past perfect form(had been failed). Hence, ‘he failed’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: He often / persists to ask / awkward questions / at the board meetings. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: persists to ask “ Persist + in + V-ing ” is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. Hence, the preposition ‘to’ must be replaced with the preposition ‘in’ and ‘persists in asking(V-ing)’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: His son-in-laws / have enhanced / his business / within a short period. SSC CGL Tier II (29 / 01 / 2022)

solution.content: His son-in-laws We can never write ‘in-laws’ because it is incorrect to add ‘s’ in the suffix(of law). However, we generally write son-in-law for a single male and sons-in-law for more than one male. Similarly, the given sentence talks about two males. Hence, ‘His sons-in-law’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: A businessman / at our colony / was found / COVID positive. SSC CGL Tier II (03 / 02 / 2022)

solution.content: At our colony The preposition ‘at’ is used when you are at a specific address, at a general location, and at a point. However, the preposition ‘in’ is used in a space, neighborhood, city and country. Similarly, the given sentence talks about a businessman in the neighborhood(colony). Hence, ‘in our colony’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Either of these / two roads / lead to / the post office. SSC CGL Tier II (03 / 02 / 2022)

solution.content: lead to According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement Rule ”, ‘ Either of/ Neither of + Plural Subject + Singular verb ’ is grammatically the correct structure. The given sentence has ‘Roads’ as a plural subject and ‘leads’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘leads to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: His father / prevented him / to go abroad / for higher studies. SSC CGL Tier II (03 / 02 / 2022)

solution.content: to go abroad We generally use the preposition ‘from’ with prevent not ‘to’. Hence, we will replace ‘to’ with ‘from’ and ‘from going abroad’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: What is the name / of the Swami / whom autobiography / impressed you so much? SSC CGL Tier II (03 / 02 / 2022)

solution.content: whom autobiography 'Whom' is an object pronoun that refers to the person who was the recipient of an action. However, 'Whose' is a possessive pronoun that refers to the person to whom something belongs. Similarly, the given sentence refers to a Swami to whom the autobiography belongs. Hence, ‘whose autobiography’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The crowd of the migrant worker at the station for the Shramik Special is unforgettable. SSC CGL Tier II (03 / 02 / 2022)

solution.content: of the migrant worker ‘Crowd’ means a large number of people in one place and these people are migrant workers(not a single worker) in the given sentence. However, it is irrelevant to use the definite article ‘the’ as the workers are not specific. Hence, ‘of migrant workers’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Will you / listen me / when I tell you / the details? SSC MTS 05 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: listen me There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘to’ is missing after ‘listen’. Hence, ‘listen to me’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The crow held back / to the piece / of bread / with its claws. SSC MTS 05 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: The crow held back ‘Held back’ means to not do something & ‘held on’ means to maintain a grasp on something.Both are phrasal verbs. Similarly, in the given sentence, the crow grasps the piece of bread with its claws. Hence, ‘the crow held on’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The farmer is / cutting the corn / which has ripen / in the fields. SSC MTS 06 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: which has ripen ‘Has + V 3 ’ is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. However, the V 3 form of ‘ripen’ is ‘ripened’. Hence, ‘has ripened’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I was told that we would met at five in the evening but no one has turned up for the meeting so far. SSC MTS 06 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content:
we would met The form of the verb ‘meet’ is incorrect(met) in the context of the given sentence. It should be written in the simple present
form(meet). Hence, ‘we would meet’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Obi wanted / to continue on / his idea of / building a modern school. SSC MTS 06 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: to continue on There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. Use the preposition ‘on’ in place of ‘with’. Hence, ‘to continue with’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Since India has started doing well in hockey it had once again become a popular sport. SSC MTS 07 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: it had once again The given sentence is in the present perfect tense so the verb must be used in the present perfect form and not in the past perfect form. Hence, ‘it has once again’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Life without laughter would be a dull affair. SSC MTS 08 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: The sports teacher was elated when his team was won the state football championship. SSC MTS 11 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: was won The positioning of the helping verb ‘was’ is incorrect in the context of the given sentence. Hence, ‘was’ will be removed & ‘when his team won’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I was watching a whole scene very carefully. SSC MTS 12 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: a whole scene The subject ‘whole scene’ is specific & before specific or particular nouns, we use the definite article ‘the’. Hence, ‘the whole scene’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Who has distributed these sweets among the children? SSC MTS 12 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Tejaswin, the Indian sportsman, is leading the anti-race cause in the US. SSC MTS 12 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: the anti-race cause The phrase ‘anti-racism’ which means the policy or practice of opposing racism and promoting racial tolerance will replace the phrase ‘anti-race’ to grammatically correct the given sentence.

question.content: Google has set on an India fund and announced an investment of ten billion dollars. SSC MTS 12 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: Google has set on There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘on’ will be replaced with ‘up’. Hence, ‘Google has set up’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: I was thrilled to going out with my friend for the film. SSC MTS 13 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: to going out The structure ‘thrilled to + V 1 ’ is grammatically correct. Hence, ‘thrilled to go(V 1 ) out’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Rohit said that he would save me from been scold by father. SSC MTS 13 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: been scold “being + V 3 (third form of the verb)” is the correct grammatical structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘being scolded(V 3 )’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Mr. Choudhri goes to fly to Germany and France next weekend. SSC MTS 14 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: Mr. Choudhri goes The given sentence talks about a future action(next weekend), . The structure ‘is going to’ is generally used for future actions. Hence, ‘Mr. Choudhri is going to’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Not get into the car; it has not been cleaned inside. SSC MTS 14 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: Not get The given sentence must start with a verb ‘do’ which is missing. Hence, ‘Do not get’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Mr. Roy was not only very successful and humble also. SSC MTS 14 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: and humble also “Not only- But also” is a fixed conjunction pair. Hence, ‘but also humble’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The man we met was any other than the original owner of the house. SSC MTS 14 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: was any other The phrase ‘any other’ will be replaced with ‘different’ which means not the same person. Hence, ‘was different than’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: “You can meet me always you like,” our teacher told us. SSC MTS 18 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: me always The word ‘always’ must be replaced with an adverb ‘anytime’ to grammatically correct the given sentence.

question.content: The man whose sitting at the corner table is my uncle. SSC MTS 18 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: whose sitting The pronoun ‘whose’ must be removed from the sentence as it is incorrect to use it with another possessive pronoun ‘my’. Hence, ‘The man sitting’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Jagdeep, the Bollywood comedian, began his film career at eight as a live childlike actor in the 1950’s. SSC MTS 20 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: as a live childlike actor The usage of the word live is incorrect. The word lively will be used here as an adjective. Lively means full of energy and excitement.

question.content: Hundred and fifty rupees seem a high price for this little vase. SSC MTS 20 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: seem a high price The amount, Time, Distance, etc are considered as singular units and singular verbs are used for them. For example, that hundred rupee note is mine. I feel a six-hour-long journey is exhausting for me, etc. Similarly in the given sentence ‘Hundred and fifty rupees’ is a singular subject that will take ‘seems’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘seems a high price’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: There is no one else in this house; I can feel the presence. SSC MTS 22 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: no one else If one can feel the presence, it is obvious that there is someone present. Hence, ‘no one’ will be replaced with ‘someone’ to make the given sentence grammatically correct.

question.content: You look very tired; you would go to bed now. SSC MTS 22 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: you would go There is a modal verb error in the given sentence. The modal verb ‘would’ must be replaced with ‘should’ as the sentence is showing a sense of suggestion. Hence, ‘you should go’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The little baby cried loudly to a new toy. SSC MTS 22 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: to a ‘Cry for something’ is a phrase that means to express a want or need through crying. Similarly in the given sentence, the child is expressing his need for the toy through crying. Hence, ‘for a toy’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: My sister prefers tea than coffee in the afternoon after lunch. SSC MTS 26 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: tea than coffee The word ‘prefer’ always takes the preposition ‘to’. Hence, ‘prefers tea to coffee’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: This is the place here Sudhir found the wallet full of money. SSC MTS 26 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: here Sudhir ‘Where’ means in or to what place or position. The given sentence talks about a place where Sudhir found the wallet full of money. Hence, ‘where’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Although we took all precautions but we were unable to avoid getting caught in the heavy rain. SSC MTS 26 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

options.text: Although we took all precautions but

answer: Although we took all precautions but

solution.content: Although we took all precautions but The ‘precautions’ mentioned in the given sentence are specific & we use the definite article ‘the’ before specific or particular nouns. We need not use the conjunction “but” as the word “although’ is the beginning of the sentence shows the contrast. Hence, ‘Although we took all the precautions ’ is the most appropriate answer. Correct sentence- Although we took all the precautions we were unable to avoid getting caught in the heavy rain.

question.content: I’m sure that I found the place without any difficulty when I go next time. SSC MTS 26 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: I found the place The given sentence shows an action of future tense(next time) so the verb must be used in its future form(will) and not in the past form(found). Hence, ‘I will find the place’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: As soon the ceremony was over, the champions would walk in a majestic procession. SSC MTS 27 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

options.text: As soon the ceremony was over

answer: As soon the ceremony was over

solution.content: As soon the ceremony was over ‘As soon as’ is the phrase that means something happening immediately after the other thing. However, the phrase is incomplete in the given sentence. Hence, ‘as soon as’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Asking for and giving informations is an important feature of conversations. SSC MTS 27 / 10 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: giving informations Some Nouns like Cattle, work, Information, Scenery, Furniture , etc. are always written in the singular form so we can't make their plural form. For example, ‘furniture’ is correct but ‘furnitures’ is incorrect. Similarly in the given sentence, ‘informations’ will be replaced with ‘information’.

question.content: My father made me to do the French grammar exercise again and again. SSC MTS 27 / 10 / 2021 (Afternoon)

options.text: My father made me to do

answer: My father made me to do

solution.content: My father made me to do ‘Made’ never take the preposition ‘to’ with it. Hence, ‘to’ will be removed from the sentence & ‘My father made me do’ becomes the most appropriate answer.

question.content: They could be pass their exams if they studied harder. SSC MTS 27 / 10 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: They could be The given sentence is in the simple past tense so the verb must be used in its past form(would). Hence, ‘They would pass’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Every country tries to do its good at the Olympic games as they are held in great prestige. SSC MTS 02 / 11 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: its good Replace “its good” by “well”. Good' is an adjective like a good boy, a good book, etc & 'Well' is an adverb like, He performed well. Similarly, in the given sentence, we need an adverb to modify the verb 'do'. Hence, 'well' is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: Judy solved the difficult problem by her own without anyone’s help. SSC MTS 02 / 11 / 2021(Evening)

solution.content: by her own There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘by’ must be replaced with ‘on’. Hence, ‘on her own’ is the most appropriate structure. “On her own” means by herself and unaided.

question.content: You must avoid riding in a crowded bus / or travelling in a metro / during rush hour / as both are quiet unpleasant experiences. SSC CGL 13 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

options.text: You must avoid riding in a crowded bus
as both are quiet unpleasant experiences

answer: as both are quiet unpleasant experiences

solution.content:
as both are quiet unpleasant experiences Quiet is an adjective that means with very little or no noise & ‘Quite’ is an adverb that is used for emphasizing something.
However, the given sentence does not talk about any sound or noise. Hence, ‘both are quite unpleasant experiences’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The river appears to have / got its name / from the town nearby. SSC CGL 13 / 08 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: got its name to + have + V 3 so, the right sentence will be, 'The river appears to have gotten its name from the town nearby.' Therefore, option c will be the right answer.

question.content: The Principal requested / the teacher’s / to monitor / and take care of the small children. SSC CGL 16 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

options.text: and take care of the small children

solution.content: the teacher’s We use apostrophes (‘s) when we want to show possession for example- t’hat is Dheeraj’s book.’ But according to the given sentence, the Principal requested the teachers to monitor and take care of the small children. So, there is no case of possession. Hence, ‘the teachers’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The recruiters / were pleased / to John’s / domain knowledge and personality. SSC CGL 16 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: to John’s The phrase ‘ someone is pleased with something(Object) ’ is grammatically correct structure, for example, I am pleased with his kind behavior. Similarly, in the given sentence, the recruiters were pleased with John’s domain knowledge and personality. Hence, ‘with John’s’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Won’t you / please come / to help me / along this heavy box? SSC CGL 17 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: along this heavy box The phrase “Would/Will/Can you help me with this______” is grammatically the correct structure that we use when we ask someone for help in doing something. Similarly, in the given sentence, the narrator is asking someone to help him/her lift a heavy bag. Hence, ‘with this heavy box’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The construction of the new business school is led to a sudden rise of population in our area. SSC CGL 17 / 08 / 2021 (Afternoon)

options.text: a sudden rise of population in our area

solution.content: is led to The given sentence is in the present perfect tense so the verb must be used in its present perfect form(has) and not in the present/base form(is). Hence, ‘has led to’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: When she went for a walk / Maya couldn't take off her scarf / because it was / too much windy. SSC CGL 17 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

options.text: Maya couldn't take off her scarf
When she went for a walk

solution.content: too much windy We use "too much" before uncountable nouns like too much money(uncountable), too much milk, etc. However, "too many" is used before countable nouns like too many shoes(countable), too many books, etc. But, in the given sentence, ‘windy’ is not a noun it is an adjective. So, we will remove ‘much’ before ‘windy’. Hence, either ‘too windy’ or ‘too much wind(noun)’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: We don't really / want a large house; / we are looking for some comfort / and some convenience on a moderate price. SSC CGL 18 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

options.text: and some convenience on a moderate price
we are looking for some comfort

answer: and some convenience on a moderate price

solution.content: and some convenience on a moderate price There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘on’ will be replaced with ‘at’ because we generally buy something at a low/high price, not on a low/high price. Hence, ‘some convenience at a moderate price’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Lalitha will go / to sister’s house / in Mumbai / this summer. SSC CGL18 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: to sister’s house There is a pronoun error in the given sentence. The possessive pronoun ‘her’ that is generally used for a female subject(Lalitha in the given sentence) is missing. Hence, ‘to her sister’s house’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: I never miss / a cricket match / as I am fond of cricket / from childhood. SSC CGL 20 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

options.text: as I am fond of cricket

solution.content: from childhood ‘Since’ is used to describe an action or situation that began in the past and continues in the present. For example, they have been married since 1990. Similarly, in the given sentence, the narrator was fond of cricket in the past and he continues this fondness in the present so he never misses a match. Hence, ‘since childhood’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Several prominent film stars / have appeared on television / on behalf of awareness / about hand hygiene. SSC CGL 23 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: on behalf of awareness The phrase ‘on behalf of the’ means as a representative of someone or something. However, in the given sentence, article ‘the’ is missing from the phrase. Hence, ‘on behalf of the awareness’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The concept became / too much clear to me / after my tutor / showed me the diagram. SSC CGL 23 / 08 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: too much clear to me The use of the phrase ‘too much’ is not necessary for the sentence because it is used before uncountable nouns like too much money and ‘clear’ is not a noun. Hence, ‘became clearer to me’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The balloon flew up / as soon as / the man cutting the string. SSC CGL 23 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: the man cutting the string The given sentence is in the past tense(flew) so the verb must be used in its simple past form(cut) and not in the present continuous form(cutting). Hence, ‘the man cut the string ’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Mithila art tradition is passed on / from one generation through a next / by children watching and helping / their mothers and grandmothers. SSC CGL 24 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

options.text: from one generation through a next
Mithila art tradition is passed on

answer: from one generation through a next

solution.content: from one generation through a next There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘through’ must be replaced with ‘to’. Hence, ‘from one generation to the next’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Electric heaters were providing to all the officers at the guest house. SSC CHSL 12 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: were providing The given sentence is in the passive voice so the verb must be used in its past form(provided) and not in the continuous form(providing). Hence, ‘were provided’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Einstein’s school teachers thought he would never success in life. SSC CHSL 12 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: never success Succeed is a verb that means to manage to achieve what you want. But, success is a noun. However, the given sentence needs a verb. Hence, ‘never succeed’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: That man would have attacked you, if you went that way. SSC CHSL 13 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: if you went “If + sub + Had + V 3 …….would have + V 3 ” is grammatically the correct structure for the given sentence. Hence, ‘If you had gone’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Employees were given incentives based at their performance. SSC CHSL 13 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: based at The phrase ‘based at’ is used to refer to the main place where you live or work & the phrase ‘based on’ means to use particular ideas or facts to make a decision. However, the given sentence states that employees were given incentives based on their performance. Hence, ‘based on’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Economists have declared that 2020 graduates will face the worse job depression since the Great Depression because of the COVID-19 pandemic. SSC CHSL 15 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

options.text: will face the worse job depression

answer: will face the worse job depression

solution.content: will face the worse job depression Worse is used as a comparative degree like your project is worse than Rahul’s project. But, ‘worst’ is used as a superlative degree which is used to show the highest degree of anything like most beautiful, best, fastest, etc. However, the given sentence states that 2020 graduates will face job depression of the highest degree since the Great Depression. Hence, ‘will face the worst job depression’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Until I was / still a little weak, / I decided to walk home / from the metro station. SSC CHSL 16 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content:
Until I was Until is used to describe an effect that will take place & Still is used to denote the continuity of the action. In the given
sentence, the narrator described the continuity of the action of walking . So, we will remove the word ‘until’. Hence, ‘I was still a little weak’ is the most appropriate answer

question.content: The government has announced a gradual reboot of air travel who was halted two months ago due to lockdown. SSC CHSL 16 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: who was halted Replace “who” with “which”. In the given sentence, the halting of air travel due to lockdown was specific. Hence, ‘which was halted’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Keep looking, and / you are sure to find the meaning / of the word on that page. SSC CHSL 16 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

options.text: of the word on that page
you are sure to find the meaning

solution.content: No error. The sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Most hotels / offer for their guests / complimentary breakfast / during their stay there. SSC CHSL 16 / 04 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: offer for their guests There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The use of ‘for’ after ‘offer’ is irrelevant so it should be removed. Hence, ‘most hotels offer their guests complimentary breakfast’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: After a long gap, / we went shopping / last Sunday and bought / that we wanted. SSC CHSL 19 / 04 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: that we wanted ‘What’ is used to refer to the thing or things that have been mentioned or said like shopping mentioned in the given sentence. Hence, ‘what is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: I'm sorry, sir. / How many is / the fine for / returning the books late? SSC CHSL 19 / 04 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: How many is ‘Many’ is used for countable nouns, for example how many apples. However, ‘much’ is used for uncountable nouns for example how much money, how much rice, etc. Similarly in the given sentence, fine is uncountable. Hence, ‘how much is the fine for?’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: At the workshop, / they were taught how to nail / the pieces of wood together to create toys. SSC CHSL 04 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

options.text: they were taught how to nail
the pieces of wood together to create toys

solution.content: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: A probe has been ordered / by the incident / that occurred at the celebrations. SSC CHSL 05 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: by the incident ‘Probe into’ a correct phrase meaning(To begin inquiring into or investigating something). The correct sentence will be as follows: A probe has been ordered into the incident that occurred at the celebrations.

question.content: If you rent a house near your office, it will save you time as well as also money. SSC CHSL 06 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: as well as also money ‘As well as’ is a conjunction that means in addition. It connects two nouns, pronouns etc. to each other. So, use only ‘money’ in place of ‘also money’.The conjunction 'as well as' is not immediately followed by ' also'.Hence the correct sentence will be as : If you rent a house near your office, it will save you time as well as money.

question.content: Notwithstanding we were / all busy that weekend / we had to / cancel the outing. SSC CHSL 06 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: Notwithstanding we were “Notwithstanding” means “despite or in spite of something” . It is used to indicate an aspect of contrast. So, ‘Notwithstanding’ will be replaced by ‘as’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.

question.content: Every participant gave so outstanding performance that it became difficult to choose the winner. SSC CHSL 06 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: so outstanding performance Such is used for emphasizing the degree of something. The given sentence tells about a performance of outstanding degree. Hence, ‘so outstanding performance’ will be replaced by ‘such an outstanding performance’ to grammatically correct the given sentence.

question.content: The need today is for both sides / to introspect and re-examine the issue carefully / and resolve it amicably. SSC CHSL 09 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

options.text: to introspect and re-examine the issue carefully
The need today is for both sides

solution.content: No error . The sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: We are yet living in the same house. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2021 (Morning)

solution.content: yet living Still means continuing until now or until the time you are talking about and not finishing. The given sentence states that they are still living in the same house. Hence, ‘still’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Your advices were timely / and guided me / to take the right decisions. SSC CHSL 10 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: Your advices were timely ‘Advice’ does not have any plural form. Use ‘pieces of advice / Bits of advice’ in place of ‘advices’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.

question.content: Only five minutes / are allowed / for each speaker / during the function. SSC CHSL 11 / 08 / 2021 (Afternoon)

solution.content: are allowed The compound nouns (numerical + noun) are not used as the plural if a noun does the work as an adjective. Here replace ‘are’ with ‘is’ to make the sentence grammatically correct.

question.content: Cyclone Amphan roared into West Bengal on Wednesday leave behind a trail of devastation across a large area of the State. SSC CHSL 12 / 08 / 2021 (Evening)

solution.content: leave behind The later part of the sentence must be written in the past tense. Hence, ‘left behind/leaving behind’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: You need to sign / these important documents / by ink. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: by ink There is a prepositional error in the given sentence. The preposition ‘by’ must be replaced with ‘in’ because we generally write ‘in ink’ for example fill the form in blue ink, sign the cheque in ink, etc. Similarly, in the given sentence, the documents need to be signed in ink. Hence, ‘in ink’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: She speaks / very highly / of both her / daughter-in-laws. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content:
daughter-in-laws
We can never write ‘-in-laws’ because adding ‘s’ in the suffix(in-law) is wrong. However, we write daughter-in-law for a single female and daughters-in-law for more than two females. Similarly, the given sentence talks about two daughters-in-law. Hence, ‘daughters-in-law’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: His loyalty / and honesty / are above / suspect. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: suspect The phrase ‘ above suspicion ’ is used to describe someone who would never be suspected of doing anything wrong. Similarly, the given sentence states that his honesty and loyalty are above suspicion. Hence, ‘suspicion’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Parul is / ten years / elder than / her sibling. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: elder than The comparative degree ‘elder’ will not be used with ‘than’ because it will become a case of superfluousness(not necessary). Hence, ‘than’ will be replaced with ‘to’ and ‘elder to’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: He is / afraid from / all insects / that crawl. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: afraid from Afraid generally takes the preposition ‘of’ and not ‘from’. Hence, ‘afraid of’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: My neighbour is / an young businessman / who is very friendly / with everyone. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: an young businessman We use the article ‘a’ before the words starting with a Consonant (B,D,F,N,etc.) for example, a dirty shirt, a neglected department, etc. However, the article ‘an’ is used before words starting with a vowel (A,E,I,O,U) for example, an educated person, an imminent danger, etc. Hence, ‘a young(Consonant ’y’) businessman’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: He wanted to know / the reason / why his low score / in Mathematics. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: why his low score If an Interrogative sentenc e(in which a question is asked) is written in the Indirect form(speech) , then “ Wh-word(why, when, where ) + Subject + Verb ” is grammatically the correct structure for it. Hence, ‘why his(subject) score was(verb) low’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: This is / only mistake / he has made / in the dictation. SSC CPO Tier II (26 / 07 / 2021)

solution.content: only mistake The article ‘the’ is used to refer to specific or particular nouns & articles ‘a/an’ are used to modify non-specific or non-particular nouns. For example, if someone says, "Let's buy the book," it means a specific book but if someone says, "Let's buy a book," it means any book rather than a specific book. Similarly, the given sentence talks about a specific mistake. Hence, ‘the only mistake’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: I am hearing a strange noise now. SSC CPO 23 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: I am hearing Stative verbs are those verbs which express a state of condition. They do not refer to a physical action. Sense and emotions like hear, smell, see, love, hate etc are different types of stative verbs. However, these verbs can’t be used in (-ing form) for example, Hear, Smell(Correct) and Hearing, Smelling(Incorrect). Hence, ‘I hear a strange noise’ will be the answer.

question.content: All of us were a little nervous when we came into this room today. SSC CPO 23 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

options.text: when we came into this room today

solution.content: No error. The given sentence is grammatically correct.

question.content: Do you earn so much to make both ends meet? SSC CPO 23 / 11 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: so much to The phrase ‘so much’ is used to mention a definite unknown quantity and ‘much’ is used with uncountable nouns. However, when we ask about someone’s earning, we usually ask how much you earn and not how ‘so much’ you earn. Hence, ‘Do you earn much’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: You cannot lead a healthy life although you stop smoking. SSC CPO 24 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: although you It is a conditional sentence which has two conditions and starts with a negative sense(cannot). It says one cannot lead a healthy life, one does not quit smoking. Unless is a negative conditional conjunction which means ‘If___not’ and it is used to combine these two conditions. Hence, Unless will replace although.

question.content: I had to hold on to the wall to steady itself or I could have fallen. SSC CPO 24 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: to steady itself According to the context of the sentence, the reflexive pronoun ‘myself’ will replace ‘itself’ because the subject(noun)/the narrator is a human being and for living things we use ‘myself’. Hence, ‘to steady myself’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The jury are from different parts of the country. SSC CPO 24 / 11 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: are from Jury/Team/Committee are considered as a singular subject and will take a singular verb, until they are divided in their opinion/views. For example, the Jury(Singular subject) has given its decision(United) , the committee(Plural subject) are divided in their opinion(Divided). Similarly in the given question, ‘the jury is(singular verb) from different parts of the country’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Miss Marple is neither a good singer or the good stage artist. SSC CPO 24 / 11 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: stage artist With neither…….nor is used. Hence, Miss Marple is neither a good singer nor a good stage artist.This will be the correct sentence.

question.content: Rice of a best quality is available in the nearby supermarket at eighty rupee per kilo. SSC CPO 25 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: a best quality In the given sentence, the best(superlative) quality rice is mentioned and we can't use the article ‘a’ with a superlative degree. Hence, ‘Rice of the best quality’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: She picked up the books lie on the table and put them on the shelf. SSC CPO 25 / 11 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: lie on the table Lying is a non-finite verb which is acting as an adjective for the books in the given sentence. Hence, ‘Books lying on the table’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: He is over eighty and dare not read without glasses. SSC CPO 25 / 11 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: dare not read Dare means to challenge someone for something. According to the context of the sentence, we have to show the inability of the person to see and for ability/inability, we will use ‘can’ and not dare. Hence, ‘cannot read’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Before take this medicine you should consult a doctor. SSC CGL Tier II (15 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: Before take ‘Before taking’ will be the correct structure for the sentence because “before” is a preposition and a preposition is followed by a gerund.

question.content: The reason for visiting Meerut was because my mother needed to be looked after. SSC CGL Tier II (15 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: was because Using ‘the reason’ with ‘because’ is superfluousness(exceeding what is sufficient or necessary) which is unnecessary in the sentence. So, the correct structure of the sentence will be ‘the reason for visiting Meerut was , my mother needed to be looked after’.

question.content: I shall buy this book if you like it or not. SSC CGL Tier II (15 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: if you like it If is used when a statement is giving a Conditional sense (means that will occur if we do this). Whethe r is used when we have to choose between two options for eg. whether you want or not. So, ‘whether’ will be the correct sentence structure. because he wants to say that he will buy the book whether the other person likes it or not.

question.content: My grandmother is quite concerned to my progress at school. SSC CGL Tier II (15 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: to my progress ‘Concerned about’ is the correct phrase, it means to worry or concern about something. So, concern about my progress is the correct structure.

question.content: He gave such a long speech but everybody felt bored. SSC CGL Tier II (15 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: but everybody “ Such - that ” is a conjunction pair which is used to give reason. According to the given question, everybody felt bored because the person gave a long boring speech. Hence, such a boring speech that everybody gets bored will be the correct structure of the sentence.

question.content: I want you to complete this work by two days. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: by two days ‘Within’ is used as a function word to describe the limit to which something can extend and not beyond the quantity or degree or limitations. Within a certain time means before that time length has passed. In this sentence, the time limit is 2 days for completing the work. Hence, within will be used in place of by .

question.content: Poor people have run down of food supplies during the lockdown SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: run down of ‘Run out of’ is a phrase which refers to a condition of shortage of food or lack of food.This question is related to phrasal verbs.

question.content: You must be careful about what you say as you meet her. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: as you When is used for talking about the time at which something happens or happened. Hence, when you meet her will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The man played the flute and led all the mouse out of the town. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: all the mouse All the mice will be the correct structure because All will be used with mice which is a plural noun.

question.content: The tired and vexed travellers waiting at the airport for a long time SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: waiting at the airport For a long time is used to show an action of the past. However, “has/have been + Verb + ing “will be the correct structure which is used to show an action that has been running from the past and still going in the present (present perfect continuous tense). So, ‘have been waiting’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: We must plan how can we cope with the present situation. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: how can we “Wh-family(What, When, Why, How) + Subject/object + Verb” is the correct structure, if an interrogative statement comes between a sentence. Hence, how we can cope is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Zoya won the first prize in the race unless she stumbled and fell. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: unless she The sentence is Verb + ing a positive sense but unless is a negative word and it is generally used to introduce the case in which a statement is being made is not true or valid. So, we will use until in place of unless. Until means up to the point in time or the event mentioned.

question.content: He loses his tempers on the slightest provocation. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: his tempers on Temper means state of mind or feelings especially with respect to patience, outbursts of anger. There is no such word like tempers.

question.content: There was enough evidence to convict him on selling of fake medicines. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: on selling of “Of” should be removed.“Selling fake' is the most appropriate structure. For example, Sam was convicted for selling the smuggled goods.

question.content: The three of them shouted out to each another when the train started moving. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: shouted out to each another ‘One another’ is the correct phrase when we are talking about two or more persons. Here, there are three people, so ‘shouted out to one another’ is the answer.Replace each other by one another to make it correct.

question.content: This jewellery box is made from silver and is an antique piece. SSC CGL Tier II (16 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: is made from silver ‘Made of something’ is the correct structure of the sentence. For example, this ball is made of plastic, this shirt is made of cotton etc. Hence, ‘Made of silver’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: He thinks that he can get away among lying and cheating. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: among lying ‘Cheating and lying’ is the manner and for introducing the manner we use the preposition ‘by’. Hence, ‘by cheating & lying’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: He has shattered his neighbour’s window by purpose. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: by purpose When you do something ‘on purpose’, you do it intentionally. Here, he broke his neighbour’s window with intention. Hence, ‘on purpose’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The captain scored a century in a second innings. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content:
in a The is a definite article which is used when we have to specify something or when the noun is particular. In this sentence, we
are talking about the runs scored particularly in the second innings. Hence, ‘In the second innings’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Whole country applauded the courage of our soldiers. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: Whole country ‘The whole country’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: The girl besides you in high heels is my younger sister. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: The girl besides you ‘Besides’ means in addition to/extra and ‘beside’ means near or next to someone/something. Hence, ‘the girl beside(near/next to) you’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: I can explain you the reason for the delay in executing your order. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: I can explain you ‘I can explain the reason’ is the most appropriate structure. because ‘explain’ is an intransitive verb which does not allow a direct object. Similarly in the given question, ‘you’ is the direct object which should be removed, for the sentence to be grammatically correct.

question.content: As such you need any money, just write to me. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: As such you ‘If you need any money’ is the correct answer. It's a conditional sentence.

question.content: I looked him at the eye and told him all I knew. SSC CGL Tier II (18 / 11 / 2020)

solution.content: at the eye ‘Look in the eye’ is an idiom which means to talk to someone in an honest way that shows no doubts. Hence, ‘I looked in the eye’ is the most appropriate structure.

question.content: Freedom of expression meaning the right to express one’s own convictions and beliefs. SSC CHSL 12 / 10 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content:
meaning the right “Meaning the right” will be replaced by “means the right”. The
sentence will be in Present indefinite tense as it is a fact. The correct sentence will be - Freedom of expression means the right to express one’s own convictions and beliefs.

question.content: We noticed that most of the shoppers in the mall looking for packets of ready to cook food SSC CHSL 13 / 10 / 2020 (Evening)

options.text: packets of ready to cook food

solution.content: in the mall looking for According to the ‘Subject-Verb agreement rule’, a singular subject takes a singular verb and a plural subject takes a plural verb. In the given question, most of the shoppers will be considered as a plural subject which will take ‘were’ as a plural verb. Hence, ‘most of the shoppers in the mall were looking for will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Yesterday I searched in every my cupboard for the shirt I couldn’t find. SSC CHSL 14 / 10 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: in every my cupboard The preposition in will be used before the pronoun (my) and every. In my every cupboard will be the most appropriate answer because my shows the possession.

question.content: A panel has been formed to look within the security needs of college students. SSC CHSL 14 / 10 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: to look within To look into means to investigate something. According to the question, a panel has been formed to investigate the security needs of college students. Hence, ‘to look into’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The Commonwealth Games had a grand opening ceremony with spectacular cultural performings. SSC CHSL 15 / 10 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: cultural performings Replace ‘performings’ with ‘performances’. Hence, ‘cultural performances’ is the most appropriate answer.

question.content: The park was well lighted at night but it was deserted, so it was a bit scared. SSC CHSL 15 / 10 / 2020 (Evening)

options.text: so it was a bit scared

answer: so it was a bit scared

solution.content: so it was a bit scared ‘It was a bit scary’ is the correct phrase. Scary is an adjective and an adjective will be used.

question.content: All these boys have come to college without few knowledge of English SSC CHSL 19 / 10 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: without few knowledge ‘knowledge’ is an uncountable noun. Correct Sentence- All these boys have come to college without any knowledge of English. Replace few with any.

question.content: The wedding reception will be hosted in Mumbai at a late date SSC CHSL 20 / 10 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: at a late date Late means ‘after the usual or expected time’ and later means ‘at a time in the near future’. So according to the context of the sentence ‘later’ will be used instead of ‘late’.

question.content: The old woman in our locality is knowing for her hot temper. SSC CHSL 20 / 10 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: is knowing for Replace “knowing” with “known” because the given sentence is in passive voice, so third form of the verb will be used. The old woman in our locality is known for her hot temper. (Correct)

question.content: People with full time sedentary jobs who commuting long distances, may have sleep problems due to lack of exercise. SSC CHSL 21 / 10 / 2020 (Morning)

options.text: People with full time sedentary jobs

solution.content: who commuting long distances Use “who commute long distances” in place of “who commuting long distances”. Who is the relative pronoun here. The antecedent for who is “jobs”. According to the pronoun rule the verb used after the relative pronoun(who) will be according to the antecedent (jobs) so the verb will be plural and “commute” will be used. So, “People with full time sedentary jobs who commute long distances, may have sleep problems due to lack of exercise” is the correct sentence.

question.content: They had to wait for the luggages to be put into the cab before they themselves got into it. SSC CHSL 17 / 03 / 2020 (Morning)

options.text: to be put into the cab
before they themselves got into it

solution.content: for the luggages Plural form of luggage is also luggage. So, “They had to wait for the luggage to be put into the cab before they themselves got into it” is grammatically correct.

question.content: We were busy at the work and went for lunch only at 2.30 pm. SSC CHSL 17 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: at the work ‘At work’ is a correct phrase. So, ‘We were busy at work and went for lunch only at 2.30 pm’ is the correct sentence.

question.content: Though she was able to finish the work on time, she couldn't do that out in fear. SSC CHSL 18 / 03 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: out in fear Out of fear - a feeling of distress. So, ‘Though she was able to finish the work on time, she couldn't do that out of fear.’ is the correct sentence.

question.content: Thomas is a man of word who have been paying back the borrowed money in instalments. SSC CHSL 18 / 03 / 2020 (Morning)

options.text: Thomas is a man of word

solution.content: who have been paying back ‘Who’ is a relative pronoun. The antecedent for who is “word” which is singular so “has” will be used. Here, man is a singular countable noun. Hence, the singular verb ‘has’ should be used for it.

question.content: It is difficult to make out that they are twins because they do not resemble to each other. SSC CHSL 18 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

options.text: It is difficult to make out

solution.content: resemble to each other ‘Resemble’ does not take any preposition with it. So, ‘It is difficult to make out that they are twins because they do not resemble each other.’ is the correct sentence.

question.content: Some of the issues discussed on the media nowadays has no relevance to the nation- building process. SSC CHSL 19 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: has no relevance “Issues” is a plural noun so the plural verb ‘Have’ is used with the subject ‘some of the issues’.

question.content: The modern man is busy acquiring more and more wealth and designing ways to invest it in more sense pleasures. SSC CGL 03 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: in more sense pleasures The word ‘sense’ is incorrect according to the context of the sentence so it will be replaced by ‘sensuous’ which means relating to or providing pleasure through gratification of the senses, for the sake of aesthetic pleasure. Hence, ‘in more sensuous pleasures’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Deepa walked down the road slowly without looking anybody. SSC CGL 03 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: looking anybody ‘Look at’ means to direct your eyes towards someone or something so that you can see them. Hence, ‘looking at anybody’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: One of the greatest responsibilities of a scientist is that his discoveries and inventions are utilized to the overall development of the nation. SSC CGL 05 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

options.text: One of the greatest responsibilities of a scientist
is that his discoveries and inventions

solution.content: are utilized to the overall The preposition ‘to’ is incorrect according to the context of the sentence so it will be replaced by ‘for’. Hence, ‘are utilized for the overall’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Those who are late they will not be allowed inside the classroom. SSC CGL 06 / 03 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: they will not be allowed ‘They’ should be removed from the sentence because ‘who’ is a relative pronoun for the main pronoun ‘those’, so there is no need to add an extra pronoun(they) in the same sentence. Hence, ‘those who are late will not be allowed’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: We had a long discussion at a cup of coffee. SSC CGL 06 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: at a cup The preposition “over” must be used with “discussion” and it will replace ‘at’ to make the sentence grammatically correct. Hence, ‘over a cup’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The both children go to the same school. SSC CGL 06 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: The both In the given sentence, ‘The both’ should be replaced by ‘Both the’ to make it grammatically correct. Hence, ‘both the children’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: All employees of the National Sugar Factory differ from their boss on the medical and pension policy. SSC CGL 06 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

options.text: on the medical and pension policy

solution.content: differ from their boss ‘Differ from' is used to imply 'unlike' (as in one thing differing from the other). However, 'Differ with' is used to imply 'disagreement' (as in differing with a point of view). In the given sentence, the employees differ with their boss on the pension policy. Hence, ‘differ with their boss’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: He married with a rich heiress last year. SSC CGL 07 / 03 / 2020 (Morning)

solution.content: with a rich heiress The preposition ‘with’ is incorrect according to the context of the given sentence. Hence, ‘he married a rich heiress’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: As a little child she was afraid from darkness. SSC CGL 07 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: from darkness In the given sentence, we will use 'afraid of darkness' in place of 'afraid from' to make the sentence grammatically correct. Hence, ‘of darkness’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: We must get this post send as soon as possible. SSC CGL 09 / 03 / 2020 (Afternoon)

solution.content: send as In this given sentence, ‘get’ is used in a causative manner, so the verb that will follow ‘get’ should be in the past participle form such as we must get this post sent(past participle form) as soon as possible. Hence, ‘get this post sent’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The big ship sank and everyone abroad drowned. SSC CGL 09 / 03 / 2020 (Evening)

solution.content: abroad drowned. In the given sentence, instead of ‘abroad’ ‘ on board’ should be used because ‘Abroad’ means in or to a foreign country or countries & ‘On board’ means available or situated on a ship, aircraft, or another vehicle. Hence, ‘on board’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: In about two weeks our holidays will start. SSC CPO 09 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: Across his morning walk on a beach in Mamallapuram, Prime Minister Modi was seen picking up plastic litter, bottles and other items. SSC CPO 09 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: Across his morning walk During is used to show that something is or was happening when something else occurred. ‘Across’ means from one side to the other of something which has sides or limits such as a city, road, or river. Hence, ‘’during his morning walk’ instead of ‘across his morning walk’.

question.content: The Government is setting up a special surveillance cell for epidemic-prone diseases at flood-ravaged Bihar. SSC CPO 09 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

solution.content: at flood-ravaged Bihar ‘At’ is used for a smaller region whereas ‘In’ is used for a bigger place. For example, I live at Mukherjee Nagar in Delhi. According to the given sentence, Bihar will be considered a bigger place. Hence, ‘in flood-ravaged Bihar’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: With food granaries overflowing, the Government is looking to liquidate his grain stock to prevent damage. SSC CPO 11 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: to liquidate his grain stock In the given sentence, the reference made is to the government, therefore, the subject should be of neutral gender. Hence, instead of ‘his’ we will use ‘its’ because his/her are used for living beings. Hence, ‘to liquidate its grain stock’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: We will have to walk now since we had missed the bus. SSC CPO 11 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

solution.content: since we had “ Future tense + Since + Present perfect tense ” is grammatically the correct structure for the given sentence. However, ‘had’ is a verb in past perfect form so it will be replaced by ‘have’. Hence, ‘since we have’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: These facts should not have been disclosed for the public. SSC CPO 11 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

solution.content: for the public Instead of ‘disclosed for’ we will use ‘disclosed to’ because ‘disclose’ takes a fixed preposition ‘to’. Hence, ‘disclosed to the public’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: If she left now, she would reach the station on time. SSC CPO 12 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: He wouldn't let anyone to drive his new car. SSC CPO 12 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: anyone to drive ‘Let’ is always followed by a verb in the infinitive form(without ‘to’) in a sentence that is in the active voice. So, the preposition ‘to’ should be removed from the sentence. Hence, ‘anyone drive’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Whom did you give the packets to? SSC CPO 12 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: I wish I have worked harder than I did SSC CPO 13 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: I have worked We use ‘ wish + Past perfect form of the verb ’ to show that we regret something(we want something in the past to be different). For example, I wish I had listened to my mom and studied harder. Hence, ‘I had’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: I ordered his dismissal when he flouted the company rules. SSC CPO 13 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: Fate smiled above him in all his business ventures SSC CPO 13 / 12 / 2019 (Morning)

solution.content: Fate smiled above him ‘Smiled on(upon)’ is a phrasal verb that means to be favourable to someone or something. Hence, ‘fate smiled on him’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Only one copy of the book, running into 1200 pages, on Gandhiji's visit to the State of Andhra Pradesh, remain now. SSC CPO 13 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

options.text: on Gandhiji's visit to the State
Only one copy of the book

solution.content: remain now According to the “ Subject-Verb Agreement rule ”, a singular subject takes a singular verb and a plural subject takes a plural verb. In the given question, ‘only one copy’ is a singular subject that will take ‘remains’ as a singular verb. Hence, ‘remains now’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: If the growth of population had been controlled earlier, mankind wouldn't live in a polluted world now. SSC CPO 13 / 12 / 2019 (Evening)

solution.content: mankind wouldn't live “ If + past perfect, Subject + would + have + 3rd form of the verb ” is grammatically the correct structure of the given sentence. Hence, ‘wouldn’t have lived’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: My father did never have an opportunity to go to a University. SSC CPO Tier II (27 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: did never have Either we will use “Do/did + not + verb” or will use ‘never + verb’. Both are grammatically the correct structures for the given sentence. Hence, ‘did not/never had’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: We reserved tickets for a journey on train for the next morning for my sisters and me. SSC CPO Tier II (27 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: for a journey on train Journey by train/car/bus is grammatically the correct structure of the sentence. Hence, ‘for a journey by train’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: The Principal was extremely angry on the boys who threw the pieces of chalk at the teacher. SSC CPO Tier II (27 / 09 / 2019)

options.text: who threw the pieces of chalk

solution.content: extremely angry on the boys Either we will use ‘angry at something’ or will use ‘angry with someone’. Hence, ‘extremely angry with the boys’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: No matter he tries hard he cannot play the guitar. SSC CPO Tier II (27 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: he tries hard “ No matter + Wh-word(how/what/whose) + adjective+ subject ” is grammatically the correct structure of the sentence. Hence, ‘no matter how hard he tries‘’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: News of the calamity is reached the family members the next day. SSC CPO Tier II (27 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: is reached There is no passive form of Intransitive verbs like arrive, reach, enter, etc. So, it is incorrect to write ‘is reached’. Hence, ‘reached’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: This summer, I’ve met down a lot of interesting people. SSC CGL Tier II (11 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: I’ve met down ‘Met down’ should be replaced by ‘met’. Hence, ‘I have met a lot of interesting people’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Does an English examination begin at 10 o’clock? SSC CGL Tier II (11 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: Does an According to the given sentence, the article ‘the’ should be used in the place of ‘an’ because the sentence talks about a particular examination. Hence, ‘Does the’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: He likes to put all the garbage into a black small bag . SSC CGL Tier II (11 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: black small bag ‘black small bag’ should be replaced with “ small black bag” The order of adjectives in English is opinion, size, age, shape, color, origin, material, and purpose. In the given sentence, ‘black’ is the adjective of color so it should follow the adjective of size ‘small’. Hence, ‘black small bag’ should be replaced with “ small black bag”.

question.content: It takes me one hour to get to work in the morning in week day. SSC CGL Tier II (11 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: in week day We never use ‘in weekends/weekdays. We use ‘on weekend/weekdays. For example, we all go to the office on weekdays, I do parties on weekends. Hence, ‘on weekdays’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: We have sufficient food and clothing about the flood victims in Kerala. SSC CGL Tier II (12 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: about the flood victims The preposition ‘about’ is incorrect according to the context of the sentence so it will be replaced by ‘for’. Hence, ‘for the flood victims’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: What is the function of the kidney in the body? SSC CGL Tier II (12 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: No error.

question.content: The Social Media Department is headless at the moment and many are vying to the post. SSC CGL Tier II (12 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content:
to the post The phrase ‘vie for (something)’ is grammatically the correct structure for the given sentence. It means to struggle, fight, or
compete in order to attain something. Hence, ‘vying for the post’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Each film will be checked by a government-appointed censor board along public exhibition. SSC CGL Tier II (13 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: along public exhibition. According to the context of the sentence, ‘along’ should be replaced with ‘before’ to make it grammatically correct. Hence, ‘before public exhibition’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: It is be said that in 2019 the Indian Stock Market will fall drastically and we can expect that fall very soon. SSC CGL Tier II (13 / 09 / 2019)

options.text: the Indian Stock Market will fall

solution.content: It is be said We cannot use ‘is’ and ‘be’ together so ‘be’ will be removed from the given sentence to make it grammatically correct. Hence, ‘It is being said’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: It was a really bad movie- a worse movie I’ve ever seen in my life. SSC CGL Tier II (13 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: a worse A superlative degree will be used in the given sentence because the narrator has never seen such a movie. However, ‘worst’ is the superlative degree of ‘worse’ and we use the article ‘the’ before ‘worst’. Hence, ‘the worst’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Since a meeting drew to a close, I realized that people were not really listening to me. SSC CGL Tier II (13 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: Since a meeting Since is sometimes also used to show the reason. However, the definite article ‘the’ is used before the meeting. Hence, ‘since the meeting’ will be the correct sentence structure.

question.content: Please don’t disturbs to me as I am reading a book. SSC CGL Tier II (13 / 09 / 2019)

solution.content: disturbs to me ‘Disturbs’ is an incorrect form of the verb used in the given sentence because with ‘do’ or ‘did’ we don’t use the ‘-s’ form of the verb. Hence, ‘disturb me’ will be the correct sentence structure.
